Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Let's explore a hypothetical together. There are over four times as
many livestock as people. Farmed cattle alone weigh
nearly ten times as much as all wild mammals combined. So imagine if a wizard of meatless
dining suddenly appeared and with one wave of a wand wiped
away all meat from our shelves— along with any desire to eat it. Farm animals destined for food vanish—
whisked away to another planet. What happens in the following days,
years, and even millennia? Overnight, food related greenhouse gas
emissions drop by about 63%. We no longer get protein
and key nutrients from the approximately
70 billion chickens, 1.5 billion pigs, 300 million cattle, and 200 million tons
of fish and shellfish processed for consumption each year. To help fill this nutritional gap, our demand for fruits, vegetables,
and legumes go up— a diet that most dietitians agree contains
all of the nutrients we need for a healthy life. But initially there aren’t enough
of these foods to go around. The rise in demand causes
produce costs to soar. In regions like Mongolia, where the harsh environment makes
it difficult to grow vegetables, a sudden lack of meat leaves
people with little to eat. Cultures built around meat
lose their foundations. Members of salmon-eating tribes in the
Pacific Northwest of the United States, for example, lose not only
sustenance and livelihoods, but an integral component
of their religion. Tens of millions of anglers lose work
that was already threatened by dwindling fish populations. As the meat industry collapses, many households in developing countries
are left scrambling for income that once came from livestock farming. Some meat producers shift
to agricultural crops, which leave workers—
and neighboring communities— less susceptible to respiratory diseases
associated with livestock production. As crop agriculture expands,
prices come down. Ultimately, vegetarianism becomes less
expensive than meat-eating in most countries. Luckily, we don’t need to clear
new farmland to grow all this food. Without animals raised for meat, land that had been used to grow
feed is now available. All things considered,
our new diets require less land and water. Millions of deaths are avoided every year, thanks in part to lower rates
of heart disease, cancer, and other conditions associated
with red meat consumption. We no longer contract new pathogens
from wild animals hunted for food, or novel influenza viruses
from farmed pigs, or drug-resistant superbugs that develop
in beef cattle that have been preemptively
fed antibiotics. As the years pass,
global biodiversity rises as habitat loss, pesticide use, and other
pressures from agriculture subside. Amazonian birds have more
forest to fly over. Fewer cheetahs are shot for stalking
too close to livestock. Bee, wasp, and butterfly communities
thrive as natural areas expand. In turn, insect-pollinated crops
produce higher yields. Many ocean species rebound
from overfishing. Throughout history,
humans in traditionally vegetarian regions have evolved a genetic mutation that helps them more efficiently
process fats from plants. So over thousands of years, our bodies may evolve to make
the most of our veggies. Or we may lose some adaptations, like the
ability to extract iron from meat. Of course, a wizard will not
turn our world meatless. Though many individuals are choosing
to go vegetarian, globally, meat eating
is still on the rise. This trend spells trouble for our climate. Even if we suddenly stopped burning
fossil fuels, business as usual food systems paired
with a growing population would push global temperatures over 1.5°C
by the end of the century. Cattle are the biggest culprit. Beef and dairy production are responsible
for over 60% of all food-based emissions, while only providing around 18%
of the world's calories. In fact, diets containing modest portions
of meats like chicken often produce less greenhouse gas
than vegetarian diets high in dairy. Reducing beef, cheese, and milk
consumption could go a long way toward achieving many of the benefits
of a meatless world— no magic required.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: There are ______ times the amount of livestock as there are people on the plant
Options: A. 2, B. 4, C. 6, D. 8
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the approximate number of livestock on Earth? Options: A. 10 billion, B. 70 billion, C. 4 times as many as people, D. 1.5 billion Correct Option: C
Question 2: What happens to greenhouse gas emissions if all meat from our shelves were suddenly wiped away? Options: A. They increase by 10%, B. They decrease by 10%, C. They drop by about 63%, D. They remain the same Correct Option: C
Question 3: What would be the initial consequence of a sudden lack of meat in regions like Mongolia? Options: A. People would have more to eat, B. People would have less to eat, C. People would be unaffected, D. People would migrate to other regions Correct Option: B
Question 4: What would be the long-term consequence of reducing beef, cheese, and milk consumption? Options: A. Global temperatures would rise by 2°C, B. Global temperatures would remain the same, C. Global temperatures would be reduced by 1°C Correct Option: D
Question 5: What is the approximate percentage of food-based emissions attributed to beef and dairy production? Options: A. 10%, B. 18%, C. 30%, D. Over 60% Correct Option: D
Question 6: What would be the consequence of the meat industry collapsing in developing countries? Options: A. Households would have more income, B. Households would have less income, C. Households would be unaffected, D. Households would migrate to other countries Correct Option: B
Question 7: How would the expansion of crop agriculture affect neighboring communities? Options: A. They would be more susceptible to respiratory diseases, B. They would be less susceptible to respiratory diseases, C. They would be unaffected, D. They would migrate to other regions Correct Option: B
Question 8: What would be the consequence of a sudden lack of meat in cultures built around meat? Options: A. They would have more to eat, B. They would have less to eat, C. They would be unaffected, D. They would migrate to other cultures Correct Option: B
Question 9: What would be the consequence of reducing red meat consumption on heart disease and cancer? Options: A. Rates would increase, B. Rates would remain the same, C. Rates would decrease, D. Rates would have no effect Correct Option: C
Question 10: What would be the consequence of a wizard making meatless diets less expensive than meat-eating? Options: A. People would consume more meat, B. People would consume more vegetables, C. People would be unaffected, D. People would migrate to other diets Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The most similar generated MCQ to the ground truth MCQ is Question 1. 

Although Question 1 does not exactly match the format of the ground truth MCQ, its option C ("4 times as many as people") directly addresses the question content and intent of the ground truth MCQ, which asks for the number of times the amount of livestock as there are people on the planet.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 1.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Let's explore a hypothetical together. There are over four times as
many livestock as people. Farmed cattle alone weigh
nearly ten times as much as all wild mammals combined. So imagine if a wizard of meatless
dining suddenly appeared and with one wave of a wand wiped
away all meat from our shelves— along with any desire to eat it. Farm animals destined for food vanish—
whisked away to another planet. What happens in the following days,
years, and even millennia? Overnight, food related greenhouse gas
emissions drop by about 63%. We no longer get protein
and key nutrients from the approximately
70 billion chickens, 1.5 billion pigs, 300 million cattle, and 200 million tons
of fish and shellfish processed for consumption each year. To help fill this nutritional gap, our demand for fruits, vegetables,
and legumes go up— a diet that most dietitians agree contains
all of the nutrients we need for a healthy life. But initially there aren’t enough
of these foods to go around. The rise in demand causes
produce costs to soar. In regions like Mongolia, where the harsh environment makes
it difficult to grow vegetables, a sudden lack of meat leaves
people with little to eat. Cultures built around meat
lose their foundations. Members of salmon-eating tribes in the
Pacific Northwest of the United States, for example, lose not only
sustenance and livelihoods, but an integral component
of their religion. Tens of millions of anglers lose work
that was already threatened by dwindling fish populations. As the meat industry collapses, many households in developing countries
are left scrambling for income that once came from livestock farming. Some meat producers shift
to agricultural crops, which leave workers—
and neighboring communities— less susceptible to respiratory diseases
associated with livestock production. As crop agriculture expands,
prices come down. Ultimately, vegetarianism becomes less
expensive than meat-eating in most countries. Luckily, we don’t need to clear
new farmland to grow all this food. Without animals raised for meat, land that had been used to grow
feed is now available. All things considered,
our new diets require less land and water. Millions of deaths are avoided every year, thanks in part to lower rates
of heart disease, cancer, and other conditions associated
with red meat consumption. We no longer contract new pathogens
from wild animals hunted for food, or novel influenza viruses
from farmed pigs, or drug-resistant superbugs that develop
in beef cattle that have been preemptively
fed antibiotics. As the years pass,
global biodiversity rises as habitat loss, pesticide use, and other
pressures from agriculture subside. Amazonian birds have more
forest to fly over. Fewer cheetahs are shot for stalking
too close to livestock. Bee, wasp, and butterfly communities
thrive as natural areas expand. In turn, insect-pollinated crops
produce higher yields. Many ocean species rebound
from overfishing. Throughout history,
humans in traditionally vegetarian regions have evolved a genetic mutation that helps them more efficiently
process fats from plants. So over thousands of years, our bodies may evolve to make
the most of our veggies. Or we may lose some adaptations, like the
ability to extract iron from meat. Of course, a wizard will not
turn our world meatless. Though many individuals are choosing
to go vegetarian, globally, meat eating
is still on the rise. This trend spells trouble for our climate. Even if we suddenly stopped burning
fossil fuels, business as usual food systems paired
with a growing population would push global temperatures over 1.5°C
by the end of the century. Cattle are the biggest culprit. Beef and dairy production are responsible
for over 60% of all food-based emissions, while only providing around 18%
of the world's calories. In fact, diets containing modest portions
of meats like chicken often produce less greenhouse gas
than vegetarian diets high in dairy. Reducing beef, cheese, and milk
consumption could go a long way toward achieving many of the benefits
of a meatless world— no magic required.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: A meat-free diet requires less land and water than a meat-filled diet.
Options: A. True, B. False
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the approximate number of livestock on Earth? Options: A. 10 billion, B. 70 billion, C. 4 times as many as people, D. 1.5 billion Correct Option: C
Question 2: What happens to greenhouse gas emissions if all meat from our shelves were suddenly wiped away? Options: A. They increase by 10%, B. They decrease by 10%, C. They drop by about 63%, D. They remain the same Correct Option: C
Question 3: What would be the initial consequence of a sudden lack of meat in regions like Mongolia? Options: A. People would have more to eat, B. People would have less to eat, C. People would be unaffected, D. People would migrate to other regions Correct Option: B
Question 4: What would be the long-term consequence of reducing beef, cheese, and milk consumption? Options: A. Global temperatures would rise by 2°C, B. Global temperatures would remain the same, C. Global temperatures would be reduced by 1°C Correct Option: D
Question 5: What is the approximate percentage of food-based emissions attributed to beef and dairy production? Options: A. 10%, B. 18%, C. 30%, D. Over 60% Correct Option: D
Question 6: What would be the consequence of the meat industry collapsing in developing countries? Options: A. Households would have more income, B. Households would have less income, C. Households would be unaffected, D. Households would migrate to other countries Correct Option: B
Question 7: How would the expansion of crop agriculture affect neighboring communities? Options: A. They would be more susceptible to respiratory diseases, B. They would be less susceptible to respiratory diseases, C. They would be unaffected, D. They would migrate to other regions Correct Option: B
Question 8: What would be the consequence of a sudden lack of meat in cultures built around meat? Options: A. They would have more to eat, B. They would have less to eat, C. They would be unaffected, D. They would migrate to other cultures Correct Option: B
Question 9: What would be the consequence of reducing red meat consumption on heart disease and cancer? Options: A. Rates would increase, B. Rates would remain the same, C. Rates would decrease, D. Rates would have no effect Correct Option: C
Question 10: What would be the consequence of a wizard making meatless diets less expensive than meat-eating? Options: A. People would consume more meat, B. People would consume more vegetables, C. People would be unaffected, D. People would migrate to other diets Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is not explicitly present in the provided options. However, based on the content and intent of the ground truth MCQ, the closest match can be inferred from the information presented in the transcript and generated MCQs.

The ground truth MCQ states that a meat-free diet requires less land and water than a meat-filled diet. This information is mentioned in the transcript as "our new diets require less land and water." However, none of the generated MCQs directly ask this question.

But if we consider the overall intent of the ground truth MCQ, which is to compare the environmental impact of a meat-free diet versus a meat-filled diet, we can find some related generated MCQs. For example, Question 2 mentions the reduction in greenhouse gas emissions when all meat is wiped away, and Question 5 mentions the percentage of food-based emissions attributed to beef and dairy production.

However, if I had to choose the most similar generated MCQ based on the content and intent, I would choose Question 2, as it is the closest match in terms of environmental impact comparison.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 2

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Let's explore a hypothetical together. There are over four times as
many livestock as people. Farmed cattle alone weigh
nearly ten times as much as all wild mammals combined. So imagine if a wizard of meatless
dining suddenly appeared and with one wave of a wand wiped
away all meat from our shelves— along with any desire to eat it. Farm animals destined for food vanish—
whisked away to another planet. What happens in the following days,
years, and even millennia? Overnight, food related greenhouse gas
emissions drop by about 63%. We no longer get protein
and key nutrients from the approximately
70 billion chickens, 1.5 billion pigs, 300 million cattle, and 200 million tons
of fish and shellfish processed for consumption each year. To help fill this nutritional gap, our demand for fruits, vegetables,
and legumes go up— a diet that most dietitians agree contains
all of the nutrients we need for a healthy life. But initially there aren’t enough
of these foods to go around. The rise in demand causes
produce costs to soar. In regions like Mongolia, where the harsh environment makes
it difficult to grow vegetables, a sudden lack of meat leaves
people with little to eat. Cultures built around meat
lose their foundations. Members of salmon-eating tribes in the
Pacific Northwest of the United States, for example, lose not only
sustenance and livelihoods, but an integral component
of their religion. Tens of millions of anglers lose work
that was already threatened by dwindling fish populations. As the meat industry collapses, many households in developing countries
are left scrambling for income that once came from livestock farming. Some meat producers shift
to agricultural crops, which leave workers—
and neighboring communities— less susceptible to respiratory diseases
associated with livestock production. As crop agriculture expands,
prices come down. Ultimately, vegetarianism becomes less
expensive than meat-eating in most countries. Luckily, we don’t need to clear
new farmland to grow all this food. Without animals raised for meat, land that had been used to grow
feed is now available. All things considered,
our new diets require less land and water. Millions of deaths are avoided every year, thanks in part to lower rates
of heart disease, cancer, and other conditions associated
with red meat consumption. We no longer contract new pathogens
from wild animals hunted for food, or novel influenza viruses
from farmed pigs, or drug-resistant superbugs that develop
in beef cattle that have been preemptively
fed antibiotics. As the years pass,
global biodiversity rises as habitat loss, pesticide use, and other
pressures from agriculture subside. Amazonian birds have more
forest to fly over. Fewer cheetahs are shot for stalking
too close to livestock. Bee, wasp, and butterfly communities
thrive as natural areas expand. In turn, insect-pollinated crops
produce higher yields. Many ocean species rebound
from overfishing. Throughout history,
humans in traditionally vegetarian regions have evolved a genetic mutation that helps them more efficiently
process fats from plants. So over thousands of years, our bodies may evolve to make
the most of our veggies. Or we may lose some adaptations, like the
ability to extract iron from meat. Of course, a wizard will not
turn our world meatless. Though many individuals are choosing
to go vegetarian, globally, meat eating
is still on the rise. This trend spells trouble for our climate. Even if we suddenly stopped burning
fossil fuels, business as usual food systems paired
with a growing population would push global temperatures over 1.5°C
by the end of the century. Cattle are the biggest culprit. Beef and dairy production are responsible
for over 60% of all food-based emissions, while only providing around 18%
of the world's calories. In fact, diets containing modest portions
of meats like chicken often produce less greenhouse gas
than vegetarian diets high in dairy. Reducing beef, cheese, and milk
consumption could go a long way toward achieving many of the benefits
of a meatless world— no magic required.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What is a benefit of transitioning less or no meat?
Options: A. Less disease, B. Less cost, C. Increase health and life expectancy, D. More biodiversity, E. Higher crop yields, F. Oceans species rebound from overfishing, G. Lower greenhouse gas emissions, H. All of the above
Correct Option: None

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the approximate number of livestock on Earth? Options: A. 10 billion, B. 70 billion, C. 4 times as many as people, D. 1.5 billion Correct Option: C
Question 2: What happens to greenhouse gas emissions if all meat from our shelves were suddenly wiped away? Options: A. They increase by 10%, B. They decrease by 10%, C. They drop by about 63%, D. They remain the same Correct Option: C
Question 3: What would be the initial consequence of a sudden lack of meat in regions like Mongolia? Options: A. People would have more to eat, B. People would have less to eat, C. People would be unaffected, D. People would migrate to other regions Correct Option: B
Question 4: What would be the long-term consequence of reducing beef, cheese, and milk consumption? Options: A. Global temperatures would rise by 2°C, B. Global temperatures would remain the same, C. Global temperatures would be reduced by 1°C Correct Option: D
Question 5: What is the approximate percentage of food-based emissions attributed to beef and dairy production? Options: A. 10%, B. 18%, C. 30%, D. Over 60% Correct Option: D
Question 6: What would be the consequence of the meat industry collapsing in developing countries? Options: A. Households would have more income, B. Households would have less income, C. Households would be unaffected, D. Households would migrate to other countries Correct Option: B
Question 7: How would the expansion of crop agriculture affect neighboring communities? Options: A. They would be more susceptible to respiratory diseases, B. They would be less susceptible to respiratory diseases, C. They would be unaffected, D. They would migrate to other regions Correct Option: B
Question 8: What would be the consequence of a sudden lack of meat in cultures built around meat? Options: A. They would have more to eat, B. They would have less to eat, C. They would be unaffected, D. They would migrate to other cultures Correct Option: B
Question 9: What would be the consequence of reducing red meat consumption on heart disease and cancer? Options: A. Rates would increase, B. Rates would remain the same, C. Rates would decrease, D. Rates would have no effect Correct Option: C
Question 10: What would be the consequence of a wizard making meatless diets less expensive than meat-eating? Options: A. People would consume more meat, B. People would consume more vegetables, C. People would be unaffected, D. People would migrate to other diets Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I found that the most similar generated MCQ is not a direct match, but Question 2 is the closest in terms of question intent and content.

However, since the ground truth MCQ is asking about the benefits of transitioning to less or no meat, I looked for a generated MCQ that covers a similar aspect. Unfortunately, none of the generated MCQs exactly match the ground truth MCQ.

But if I had to choose one, I would say that Question 2 is the closest, as it talks about the reduction in greenhouse gas emissions, which is one of the benefits mentioned in the ground truth MCQ.

That being said, I would like to propose an alternative approach. Since the ground truth MCQ is asking about multiple benefits, I would suggest creating a new generated MCQ that combines the aspects of Questions 2, 5, 7, 9, and the information about biodiversity and ocean species rebounding. This new generated MCQ would more closely match the ground truth MCQ.

However, if I had to choose from the existing generated MCQs, I would say:

Index: 2

Please note that this is not an exact match, and a new generated MCQ would be needed to fully capture the intent and content of the ground truth MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Let's explore a hypothetical together. There are over four times as
many livestock as people. Farmed cattle alone weigh
nearly ten times as much as all wild mammals combined. So imagine if a wizard of meatless
dining suddenly appeared and with one wave of a wand wiped
away all meat from our shelves— along with any desire to eat it. Farm animals destined for food vanish—
whisked away to another planet. What happens in the following days,
years, and even millennia? Overnight, food related greenhouse gas
emissions drop by about 63%. We no longer get protein
and key nutrients from the approximately
70 billion chickens, 1.5 billion pigs, 300 million cattle, and 200 million tons
of fish and shellfish processed for consumption each year. To help fill this nutritional gap, our demand for fruits, vegetables,
and legumes go up— a diet that most dietitians agree contains
all of the nutrients we need for a healthy life. But initially there aren’t enough
of these foods to go around. The rise in demand causes
produce costs to soar. In regions like Mongolia, where the harsh environment makes
it difficult to grow vegetables, a sudden lack of meat leaves
people with little to eat. Cultures built around meat
lose their foundations. Members of salmon-eating tribes in the
Pacific Northwest of the United States, for example, lose not only
sustenance and livelihoods, but an integral component
of their religion. Tens of millions of anglers lose work
that was already threatened by dwindling fish populations. As the meat industry collapses, many households in developing countries
are left scrambling for income that once came from livestock farming. Some meat producers shift
to agricultural crops, which leave workers—
and neighboring communities— less susceptible to respiratory diseases
associated with livestock production. As crop agriculture expands,
prices come down. Ultimately, vegetarianism becomes less
expensive than meat-eating in most countries. Luckily, we don’t need to clear
new farmland to grow all this food. Without animals raised for meat, land that had been used to grow
feed is now available. All things considered,
our new diets require less land and water. Millions of deaths are avoided every year, thanks in part to lower rates
of heart disease, cancer, and other conditions associated
with red meat consumption. We no longer contract new pathogens
from wild animals hunted for food, or novel influenza viruses
from farmed pigs, or drug-resistant superbugs that develop
in beef cattle that have been preemptively
fed antibiotics. As the years pass,
global biodiversity rises as habitat loss, pesticide use, and other
pressures from agriculture subside. Amazonian birds have more
forest to fly over. Fewer cheetahs are shot for stalking
too close to livestock. Bee, wasp, and butterfly communities
thrive as natural areas expand. In turn, insect-pollinated crops
produce higher yields. Many ocean species rebound
from overfishing. Throughout history,
humans in traditionally vegetarian regions have evolved a genetic mutation that helps them more efficiently
process fats from plants. So over thousands of years, our bodies may evolve to make
the most of our veggies. Or we may lose some adaptations, like the
ability to extract iron from meat. Of course, a wizard will not
turn our world meatless. Though many individuals are choosing
to go vegetarian, globally, meat eating
is still on the rise. This trend spells trouble for our climate. Even if we suddenly stopped burning
fossil fuels, business as usual food systems paired
with a growing population would push global temperatures over 1.5°C
by the end of the century. Cattle are the biggest culprit. Beef and dairy production are responsible
for over 60% of all food-based emissions, while only providing around 18%
of the world's calories. In fact, diets containing modest portions
of meats like chicken often produce less greenhouse gas
than vegetarian diets high in dairy. Reducing beef, cheese, and milk
consumption could go a long way toward achieving many of the benefits
of a meatless world— no magic required.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Beef and dairy production are responsible for more than ___ of all food based emissions, while providing about ___ of the world's nutrients.
Options: A. 30%, 1%, B. 40%, 4%, C. 50%, 8%, D. 60%, 18%
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the approximate number of livestock on Earth? Options: A. 10 billion, B. 70 billion, C. 4 times as many as people, D. 1.5 billion Correct Option: C
Question 2: What happens to greenhouse gas emissions if all meat from our shelves were suddenly wiped away? Options: A. They increase by 10%, B. They decrease by 10%, C. They drop by about 63%, D. They remain the same Correct Option: C

They would be less susceptible to respiratory diseases, C. They would be unaffected, D. They would migrate to other regions Correct Option: B

Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The most similar generated MCQ to the ground truth MCQ is Question 5. 

Here's why:

- Both questions focus on the percentage of food-based emissions attributed to beef and dairy production.
- The correct options in both questions mention that beef and dairy production are responsible for over 60% of all food-based emissions.
- Although the ground truth MCQ also mentions the percentage of the world's nutrients provided by beef and dairy production, the primary focus of the question is on emissions, which is also the focus of Question 5.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 5

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Let's explore a hypothetical together. There are over four times as
many livestock as people. Farmed cattle alone weigh
nearly ten times as much as all wild mammals combined. So imagine if a wizard of meatless
dining suddenly appeared and with one wave of a wand wiped
away all meat from our shelves— along with any desire to eat it. Farm animals destined for food vanish—
whisked away to another planet. What happens in the following days,
years, and even millennia? Overnight, food related greenhouse gas
emissions drop by about 63%. We no longer get protein
and key nutrients from the approximately
70 billion chickens, 1.5 billion pigs, 300 million cattle, and 200 million tons
of fish and shellfish processed for consumption each year. To help fill this nutritional gap, our demand for fruits, vegetables,
and legumes go up— a diet that most dietitians agree contains
all of the nutrients we need for a healthy life. But initially there aren’t enough
of these foods to go around. The rise in demand causes
produce costs to soar. In regions like Mongolia, where the harsh environment makes
it difficult to grow vegetables, a sudden lack of meat leaves
people with little to eat. Cultures built around meat
lose their foundations. Members of salmon-eating tribes in the
Pacific Northwest of the United States, for example, lose not only
sustenance and livelihoods, but an integral component
of their religion. Tens of millions of anglers lose work
that was already threatened by dwindling fish populations. As the meat industry collapses, many households in developing countries
are left scrambling for income that once came from livestock farming. Some meat producers shift
to agricultural crops, which leave workers—
and neighboring communities— less susceptible to respiratory diseases
associated with livestock production. As crop agriculture expands,
prices come down. Ultimately, vegetarianism becomes less
expensive than meat-eating in most countries. Luckily, we don’t need to clear
new farmland to grow all this food. Without animals raised for meat, land that had been used to grow
feed is now available. All things considered,
our new diets require less land and water. Millions of deaths are avoided every year, thanks in part to lower rates
of heart disease, cancer, and other conditions associated
with red meat consumption. We no longer contract new pathogens
from wild animals hunted for food, or novel influenza viruses
from farmed pigs, or drug-resistant superbugs that develop
in beef cattle that have been preemptively
fed antibiotics. As the years pass,
global biodiversity rises as habitat loss, pesticide use, and other
pressures from agriculture subside. Amazonian birds have more
forest to fly over. Fewer cheetahs are shot for stalking
too close to livestock. Bee, wasp, and butterfly communities
thrive as natural areas expand. In turn, insect-pollinated crops
produce higher yields. Many ocean species rebound
from overfishing. Throughout history,
humans in traditionally vegetarian regions have evolved a genetic mutation that helps them more efficiently
process fats from plants. So over thousands of years, our bodies may evolve to make
the most of our veggies. Or we may lose some adaptations, like the
ability to extract iron from meat. Of course, a wizard will not
turn our world meatless. Though many individuals are choosing
to go vegetarian, globally, meat eating
is still on the rise. This trend spells trouble for our climate. Even if we suddenly stopped burning
fossil fuels, business as usual food systems paired
with a growing population would push global temperatures over 1.5°C
by the end of the century. Cattle are the biggest culprit. Beef and dairy production are responsible
for over 60% of all food-based emissions, while only providing around 18%
of the world's calories. In fact, diets containing modest portions
of meats like chicken often produce less greenhouse gas
than vegetarian diets high in dairy. Reducing beef, cheese, and milk
consumption could go a long way toward achieving many of the benefits
of a meatless world— no magic required.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: A high dairy vegetarian diet produces less green house gasses than meals with modest meat portions such as chicken.
Options: A. True, B. False
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the approximate number of livestock on Earth? Options: A. 10 billion, B. 70 billion, C. 4 times as many as people, D. 1.5 billion Correct Option: C
Question 2: What happens to greenhouse gas emissions if all meat from our shelves were suddenly wiped away? Options: A. They increase by 10%, B. They decrease by 10%, C. They drop by about 63%, D. They remain the same Correct Option: C
Question 3: What would be the initial consequence of a sudden lack of meat in regions like Mongolia? Options: A. People would have more to eat, B. People would have less to eat, C. People would be unaffected, D. People would migrate to other regions Correct Option: B
Question 4: What would be the long-term consequence of reducing beef, cheese, and milk consumption? Options: A. Global temperatures would rise by 2°C, B. Global temperatures would remain the same, C. Global temperatures would be reduced by 1°C Correct Option: D
Question 5: What is the approximate percentage of food-based emissions attributed to beef and dairy production? Options: A. 10%, B. 18%, C. 30%, D. Over 60% Correct Option: D
Question 6: What would be the consequence of the meat industry collapsing in developing countries? Options: A. Households would have more income, B. Households would have less income, C. Households would be unaffected, D. Households would migrate to other countries Correct Option: B
Question 7: How would the expansion of crop agriculture affect neighboring communities? Options: A. They would be more susceptible to respiratory diseases, B. They would be less susceptible to respiratory diseases, C. They would be unaffected, D. They would migrate to other regions Correct Option: B
Question 8: What would be the consequence of a sudden lack of meat in cultures built around meat? Options: A. They would have more to eat, B. They would have less to eat, C. They would be unaffected, D. They would migrate to other cultures Correct Option: B
Question 9: What would be the consequence of reducing red meat consumption on heart disease and cancer? Options: A. Rates would increase, B. Rates would remain the same, C. Rates would decrease, D. Rates would have no effect Correct Option: C
Question 10: What would be the consequence of a wizard making meatless diets less expensive than meat-eating? Options: A. People would consume more meat, B. People would consume more vegetables, C. People would be unaffected, D. People would migrate to other diets Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 2, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In 1944, 11 years before her fateful 
decision on a Montgomery Bus, Rosa Parks was investigating 
a vicious crime. As an emissary for 
the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, she had traveled to rural Alabama 
to meet with Recy Taylor, a young woman who had been 
sexually assaulted by six white men. It would be difficult enough to convince
an Alabama court that even one of these men was guilty, but Rosa was undeterred. She formed a committee to defend 
Recy in court, flooding the media with testimony and sparking protests 
throughout the South. When a jury failed 
to indict the attackers, Parks demanded the governor 
assemble a new grand jury. She wrote, “I know that you will not fail
to let the people of Alabama know that there is equal justice 
for all of our citizens.” Throughout her life, Parks repeatedly 
challenged racial violence and the prejudiced systems 
protecting its perpetrators. But this work came at an enormous risk— and a personal price. Born in 1913, Rosa was raised by her 
mother and grandparents in rural Alabama. But outside this loving home, the fear 
of racial violence cast a long shadow. The Ku Klux Klan frequently 
drove past their home, and Jim Crow laws 
segregated public spaces. At 19 she settled in Montgomery
and married Raymond Parks, a barber who shared her growing fury 
at racial injustice. He was involved with the local chapter
of the NAACP; a role many avoided 
for fear of persecution. At first Raymond was eager 
to keep Rosa safe from the potential dangers of activism. But as she grew more incensed at the
limitations imposed on African Americans, she could no longer stand by. When she officially joined 
the NAACP in 1943, Parks and Johnnie Rebecca Carr were 
the only women in the Montgomery chapter. She began keeping minutes 
for their meetings, and soon found herself elected 
secretary of the chapter— formally beginning her secret double life. By day, Rosa worked as a seamstress
to support her mother and husband. By night, she researched and documented
numerous civil rights cases, from local policy disputes to high-profile
murder cases and hate crimes. As secretary, she prepared public 
responses on behalf of the Montgomery chapter,
battling the harsh sentencing, false accusation and smear campaigns 
frequently used against African Americans. In addition to her legal work, Parks 
was a brilliant local strategist. As advisor to the NAACP 
youth group council, she helped young people navigate 
segregated systems including voter registration and 
whites-only libraries. Through the cover of the NAACP, Parks strived to bring clandestine 
civil rights activities into the open. She advocated for civil disobedience
training and spoke out against racial violence,
particularly the murder of Emmet Till. In 1955, her refusal to move 
to the back of a segregated bus helped ignite the grassroots movement 
she had hoped for. Parks was arrested and jailed 
for her one-woman protest, where she was visited by local activists. Together they planned a twenty-four 
hour bus boycott. It lasted for three hundred 
and eighty-one days. Park’s simple act had transformed 
nascent civil rights activism into a national movement. In 1956, the boycott ended 
when the Supreme Court ruled in favor of desegregating 
public transport. But this victory for the movement 
had come at a great cost. Rosa had been receiving vicious death 
threats throughout the campaign, and was unable to find work in Montgomery
because of her political reputation. In 1957, she moved to Detroit 
to continue working as a seamstress, until being hired by Congressman 
John Conyers to help support his burgeoning 
civil rights campaigns. Ever vigilant in the fight against racial 
inequality, Parks remained active 
for the next 40 years. She wrote several books, traveled across the country giving talks
to support other activists, and established an institute 
for the education of young people in her late husband’s memory. Today, Rosa Parks is remembered 
as a radical spirit who railed against the most powerful 
people and policies. Her call to action continues to resound: “knowing what must be done
does away with fear.”

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Rosa Parks’s husband Raymond Parks was in a group that advocated for the case related to
Options: A. Emmett Till, B. The Scottsboro Boys, C. Recy Taylor
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Who was Recy Taylor, and what happened to her? Options: A. She was a civil rights activist who was arrested for protesting segregation., B. She was a young woman who was sexually assaulted by six white men., C. She was a prominent figure in the Montgomery Bus Boycott., D. She was a seamstress who worked alongside Rosa Parks. Correct Option: B
Question 2: What was Rosa Parks' role in the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP)? Options: A. She was the president of the Montgomery chapter., B. She was the secretary of the Montgomery chapter., C. She was an emissary for the NAACP., D. She was a local strategist for the NAACP. Correct Option: C
Question 3: Why did Rosa Parks demand the governor assemble a new grand jury in Recy Taylor's case? Options: A. Because she was dissatisfied with the initial verdict., B. Because she wanted to ensure that justice was served., C. Because she wanted to bring attention to the case., D. Because she was seeking revenge against the perpetrators. Correct Option: B
Question 4: What was the outcome of the Montgomery Bus Boycott? Options: A. It ended in failure and Rosa Parks was arrested., B. It ended in victory when the Supreme Court ruled in favor of desegregating public transport., C. It led to a national movement for civil rights., D. It resulted in Rosa Parks being hired by Congressman John Conyers. Correct Option: B
Question 5: What was the personal price Rosa Parks paid for her activism? Options: A. She lost her job as a seamstress., B. She received vicious death threats., C. She was unable to find work in Montgomery., D. All of the above. Correct Option: D
Question 6: What was Rosa Parks' role in the NAACP youth group council? Options: A. She was an advisor to the council., B. She was the president of the council., C. She was a local strategist for the council., D. She was a civil rights activist who worked alongside the council. Correct Option: A
Question 7: Why did Rosa Parks advocate for civil disobedience training? Options: A. Because she wanted to bring attention to the civil rights movement., B. Because she wanted to challenge racial violence., C. Because she wanted to bring about change through peaceful means., D. Because she wanted to provoke a reaction from the government. Correct Option: B
Question 8: What was the significance of Rosa Parks' refusal to move to the back of the bus? Options: A. It was a minor incident that had no impact on the civil rights movement., B. It was a symbolic act that helped ignite the grassroots movement., C. It was a personal act of defiance that had no broader implications., D. It was a major incident that led to Rosa Parks' arrest and imprisonment. Correct Option: B
Question 9: What was the outcome of Rosa Parks' activism over the next 40 years? Options: A. She became a prominent figure in the civil rights movement., B. She wrote several books and traveled across the country giving talks., C. She established an institute for the education of young people., D. All of the above. Correct Option: D
Question 10: What is the message that Rosa Parks continues to convey through her activism? Options: A. Fear is a necessary motivator for change., B. Knowing what must be done does away with fear., C. Change is only possible through violent means., D. The civil rights movement is a lost cause. Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:

However, this question does not match the content of the ground truth MCQ. A more suitable match is not present among the provided options as none of the generated MCQs mention Raymond Parks or his involvement with a group advocating for a specific case.

In 1944, 11 years before her fateful 
decision on a Montgomery Bus, Rosa Parks was investigating 
a vicious crime. As an emissary for

to meet with Recy Taylor, a young woman who had been

throughout the South. When a jury failed

to let the people of Alabama know that there is equal justice 
for all of our citizens.” Throughout her life, Parks repeatedly 
challenged racial violence and the prejudiced systems

segregated public spaces. At 19 she settled in Montgomery

responses on behalf of the Montgomery chapter,
battling the harsh sentencing, false accusation and smear campaigns

for the education of young people in her late husband’s memory. Today, Rosa Parks is remembered 
as a radical spirit who railed against the most powerful 
people and policies. Her call to action continues to resound: “knowing what must be done
does away with fear.”

Matching Prompt:

In 1944, 11 years before her fateful 
decision on a Montgomery Bus, Rosa Parks was investigating 
a vicious crime. As an emissary for 
the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, she had traveled to rural Alabama 
to meet with Recy Taylor, a young woman who had been 
sexually assaulted by six white men. It would be difficult enough to convince
an Alabama court that even one of these men was guilty, but Rosa was undeterred. She formed a committee to defend 
Recy in court, flooding the media with testimony and sparking protests 
throughout the South. When a jury failed 
to indict the attackers, Parks demanded the governor 
assemble a new grand jury. She wrote, “I know that you will not fail
to let the people of Alabama know that there is equal justice 
for all of our citizens.” Throughout her life, Parks repeatedly 
challenged racial violence and the prejudiced systems 
protecting its perpetrators. But this work came at an enormous risk— and a personal price. Born in 1913, Rosa was raised by her 
mother and grandparents in rural Alabama. But outside this loving home, the fear 
of racial violence cast a long shadow. The Ku Klux Klan frequently 
drove past their home, and Jim Crow laws 
segregated public spaces. At 19 she settled in Montgomery
and married Raymond Parks, a barber who shared her growing fury 
at racial injustice. He was involved with the local chapter
of the NAACP; a role many avoided 
for fear of persecution. At first Raymond was eager 
to keep Rosa safe from the potential dangers of activism. But as she grew more incensed at the
limitations imposed on African Americans, she could no longer stand by. When she officially joined 
the NAACP in 1943, Parks and Johnnie Rebecca Carr were 
the only women in the Montgomery chapter. She began keeping minutes 
for their meetings, and soon found herself elected 
secretary of the chapter— formally beginning her secret double life. By day, Rosa worked as a seamstress
to support her mother and husband. By night, she researched and documented
numerous civil rights cases, from local policy disputes to high-profile
murder cases and hate crimes. As secretary, she prepared public 
responses on behalf of the Montgomery chapter,
battling the harsh sentencing, false accusation and smear campaigns 
frequently used against African Americans. In addition to her legal work, Parks 
was a brilliant local strategist. As advisor to the NAACP 
youth group council, she helped young people navigate 
segregated systems including voter registration and 
whites-only libraries. Through the cover of the NAACP, Parks strived to bring clandestine 
civil rights activities into the open. She advocated for civil disobedience
training and spoke out against racial violence,
particularly the murder of Emmet Till. In 1955, her refusal to move 
to the back of a segregated bus helped ignite the grassroots movement 
she had hoped for. Parks was arrested and jailed 
for her one-woman protest, where she was visited by local activists. Together they planned a twenty-four 
hour bus boycott. It lasted for three hundred 
and eighty-one days. Park’s simple act had transformed 
nascent civil rights activism into a national movement. In 1956, the boycott ended 
when the Supreme Court ruled in favor of desegregating 
public transport. But this victory for the movement 
had come at a great cost. Rosa had been receiving vicious death 
threats throughout the campaign, and was unable to find work in Montgomery
because of her political reputation. In 1957, she moved to Detroit 
to continue working as a seamstress, until being hired by Congressman 
John Conyers to help support his burgeoning 
civil rights campaigns. Ever vigilant in the fight against racial 
inequality, Parks remained active 
for the next 40 years. She wrote several books, traveled across the country giving talks
to support other activists, and established an institute 
for the education of young people in her late husband’s memory. Today, Rosa Parks is remembered 
as a radical spirit who railed against the most powerful 
people and policies. Her call to action continues to resound: “knowing what must be done
does away with fear.”

**Ground Truth MCQ**:

Options: A. Elaine Steele, B. Johnnie Rebecca Carr, C. Recy Taylor
Correct Option: B

**Transcript**:
In 1944, 11 years before her fateful 
decision on a Montgomery Bus, Rosa Parks was investigating 
a vicious crime. As an emissary for 
the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, she had traveled to rural Alabama 
to meet with Recy Taylor, a young woman who had been 
sexually assaulted by six white men. It would be difficult enough to convince
an Alabama court that even one of these men was guilty, but Rosa was undeterred. She formed a committee to defend 
Recy in court, flooding the media with testimony and sparking protests 
throughout the South. When a jury failed 
to indict the attackers, Parks demanded the governor 
assemble a new grand jury. She wrote, “I know that you will not fail
to let the people of Alabama know that there is equal justice 
for all of our citizens.” Throughout her life, Parks repeatedly 
challenged racial violence and the prejudiced systems 
protecting its perpetrators. But this work came at an enormous risk— and a personal price. Born in 1913, Rosa was raised by her 
mother and grandparents in rural Alabama. But outside this loving home, the fear 
of racial violence cast a long shadow. The Ku Klux Klan frequently 
drove past their home, and Jim Crow laws 
segregated public spaces. At 19 she settled in Montgomery
and married Raymond Parks, a barber who shared her growing fury 
at racial injustice. He was involved with the local chapter
of the NAACP; a role many avoided 
for fear of persecution. At first Raymond was eager 
to keep Rosa safe from the potential dangers of activism. But as she grew more incensed at the
limitations imposed on African Americans, she could no longer stand by. When she officially joined 
the NAACP in 1943, Parks and Johnnie Rebecca Carr were 
the only women in the Montgomery chapter. She began keeping minutes 
for their meetings, and soon found herself elected 
secretary of the chapter— formally beginning her secret double life. By day, Rosa worked as a seamstress
to support her mother and husband. By night, she researched and documented
numerous civil rights cases, from local policy disputes to high-profile
murder cases and hate crimes. As secretary, she prepared public 
responses on behalf of the Montgomery chapter,
battling the harsh sentencing, false accusation and smear campaigns 
frequently used against African Americans. In addition to her legal work, Parks 
was a brilliant local strategist. As advisor to the NAACP 
youth group council, she helped young people navigate 
segregated systems including voter registration and 
whites-only libraries. Through the cover of the NAACP, Parks strived to bring clandestine 
civil rights activities into the open. She advocated for civil disobedience
training and spoke out against racial violence,
particularly the murder of Emmet Till. In 1955, her refusal to move 
to the back of a segregated bus helped ignite the grassroots movement 
she had hoped for. Parks was arrested and jailed 
for her one-woman protest, where she was visited by local activists. Together they planned a twenty-four 
hour bus boycott. It lasted for three hundred 
and eighty-one days. Park’s simple act had transformed 
nascent civil rights activism into a national movement. In 1956, the boycott ended 
when the Supreme Court ruled in favor of desegregating 
public transport. But this victory for the movement 
had come at a great cost. Rosa had been receiving vicious death 
threats throughout the campaign, and was unable to find work in Montgomery
because of her political reputation. In 1957, she moved to Detroit 
to continue working as a seamstress, until being hired by Congressman 
John Conyers to help support his burgeoning 
civil rights campaigns. Ever vigilant in the fight against racial 
inequality, Parks remained active 
for the next 40 years. She wrote several books, traveled across the country giving talks
to support other activists, and established an institute 
for the education of young people in her late husband’s memory. Today, Rosa Parks is remembered 
as a radical spirit who railed against the most powerful 
people and policies. Her call to action continues to resound: “knowing what must be done
does away with fear.”

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 2, Question 6
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. **Transcript**:
In 1944, 11 years before her fateful 
decision on a Montgomery Bus, Rosa Parks was investigating 
a vicious crime. As an emissary for 
the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, she had traveled to rural Alabama 
to meet with Recy Taylor, a young woman who had been 
sexually assaulted by six white men. It would be difficult enough to convince
an Alabama court that even one of these men was guilty, but Rosa was undeterred. She formed a committee to defend 
Recy in court, flooding the media with testimony and sparking protests 
throughout the South. When a jury failed 
to indict the attackers, Parks demanded the governor 
assemble a new grand jury. She wrote, “I know that you will not fail
to let the people of Alabama know that there is equal justice 
for all of our citizens.” Throughout her life, Parks repeatedly 
challenged racial violence and the prejudiced systems 
protecting its perpetrators. But this work came at an enormous risk— and a personal price. Born in 1913, Rosa was raised by her 
mother and grandparents in rural Alabama. But outside this loving home, the fear 
of racial violence cast a long shadow. The Ku Klux Klan frequently 
drove past their home, and Jim Crow laws 
segregated public spaces. At 19 she settled in Montgomery
and married Raymond Parks, a barber who shared her growing fury 
at racial injustice. He was involved with the local chapter
of the NAACP; a role many avoided 
for fear of persecution. At first Raymond was eager 
to keep Rosa safe from the potential dangers of activism. But as she grew more incensed at the
limitations imposed on African Americans, she could no longer stand by. When she officially joined 
the NAACP in 1943, Parks and Johnnie Rebecca Carr were 
the only women in the Montgomery chapter. She began keeping minutes 
for their meetings, and soon found herself elected 
secretary of the chapter— formally beginning her secret double life. By day, Rosa worked as a seamstress
to support her mother and husband. By night, she researched and documented
numerous civil rights cases, from local policy disputes to high-profile
murder cases and hate crimes. As secretary, she prepared public 
responses on behalf of the Montgomery chapter,
battling the harsh sentencing, false accusation and smear campaigns 
frequently used against African Americans. In addition to her legal work, Parks 
was a brilliant local strategist. As advisor to the NAACP 
youth group council, she helped young people navigate 
segregated systems including voter registration and 
whites-only libraries. Through the cover of the NAACP, Parks strived to bring clandestine 
civil rights activities into the open. She advocated for civil disobedience
training and spoke out against racial violence,
particularly the murder of Emmet Till. In 1955, her refusal to move 
to the back of a segregated bus helped ignite the grassroots movement 
she had hoped for. Parks was arrested and jailed 
for her one-woman protest, where she was visited by local activists. Together they planned a twenty-four 
hour bus boycott. It lasted for three hundred 
and eighty-one days. Park’s simple act had transformed 
nascent civil rights activism into a national movement. In 1956, the boycott ended 
when the Supreme Court ruled in favor of desegregating 
public transport. But this victory for the movement 
had come at a great cost. Rosa had been receiving vicious death 
threats throughout the campaign, and was unable to find work in Montgomery
because of her political reputation. In 1957, she moved to Detroit 
to continue working as a seamstress, until being hired by Congressman 
John Conyers to help support his burgeoning 
civil rights campaigns. Ever vigilant in the fight against racial 
inequality, Parks remained active 
for the next 40 years. She wrote several books, traveled across the country giving talks
to support other activists, and established an institute 
for the education of young people in her late husband’s memory. Today, Rosa Parks is remembered 
as a radical spirit who railed against the most powerful 
people and policies. Her call to action continues to resound: “knowing what must be done
does away with fear.”

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 4, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In 1830 at a clothing store
near the Boston Harbor, David Walker carefully stitched
a pamphlet into the lining of a sailor’s coat. The volume was thin enough
to be completely hidden, but its content was 
far from insubstantial. In fact, at the time, many members 
of the US government considered this pamphlet to be one 
of the most dangerous documents in American history. So to ensure this volume
reached his audience, Walker had to hide his work 
in the clothing of both willing co-conspirators 
and unknowing sailors; smuggling the pamphlet 
throughout the country. But what was this incendiary document? 
And who exactly was the man who wrote it? Son of an enslaved father
and a freedwoman, David Walker was born free 
in the late 18th century in Wilmington, North Carolina. From a young age, he sought to extend 
his freedom to all Black Americans, and after moving to Charleston
as a young man, he became closely involved with the
African Methodist Episcopal Church. At that time, the mainstream movement 
to end slavery was comprised of societies led by wealthy white men 
who favored gradual change and avoided confrontation
with slaveholders. But the AME Church practiced
a more radical brand of abolition. In 1822, AME leader Denmark Vesey
planned a major insurrection intended to violently liberate 
Charleston’s enslaved community and set the city ablaze. It’s unclear if Walker contributed
to Vesey’s plan, but he wasn’t among the many AME members
who were arrested and executed for this attempted rebellion. In 1825, Walker surfaced in Boston, where
he rejoined the fight against slavery. In addition to marrying 
fellow activist Eliza Butler and opening his clothing store, Walker helped fund America’s
first Black-owned newspaper. Is passionate articles and public speeches
sought to instill pride and camaraderie into those fighting for Black liberation. But to truly unite free 
and enslaved Black Americans, Walker would have to go beyond Boston. In 1829, he poured his ideas into the “Appeal to the Colored Citizens 
of the World.” This treatise was punctuated
with furious exclamation marks and emphasized the spiritual righteousness
of resistance. He described the suffering of enslaved
people in graphic detail to prove that the reality for Black Americans
was often “kill or be killed.” And given these circumstances, Walker staunchly defended 
the right to militant action. This wasn’t his only departure 
from moderate mainstream abolitionists. To stress the importance
of Black solidarity, Walker connected American abolitionism with global movements 
for Black liberation. He called for an international 
Black freedom struggle in an early display of what would come
to be called Pan-Africanism. But at the same time, 
he opposed the popular movement for Black Americans to emigrate to Africa. While the “Appeal” criticized 
the Founding Fathers for their hypocrisy, Walker insisted that Black people were
essential to the country’s creation, and had an undeniable right
to American citizenship. Walker suspected 
these incendiary arguments would make him a target for violence. But in spite of the danger, he continued 
using sailors to smuggle his work. The “Appeal” traveled down the coast 
into the hands of shopkeepers, church leaders, political organizers, 
and underground abolitionist networks. For these readers, Walker’s words
galvanized militant efforts to overthrow slave owners and its call to arms struck fear
into white officials. Police intercepted its delivery, and quarantined Black sailors
at Southern ports. The pamphlet inspired Louisiana 
to ban anti-slavery literature, and both North and South Carolina 
cracked down on Black education to prevent literacy 
among enslaved peoples. Southern officials even placed 
a bounty on Walker’s head worth the modern equivalent
of $322,000. But while friends urged him to flee,
Walker refused to abandon his cause. Tragically, his bravery 
couldn’t protect him from the deadliest disease of his time. In August 1830, Walker was found dead. And while his associates declared
him the victim of assassination, it’s now widely believed 
that he died from tuberculosis. Following his death, Walker's message
continued to resound. Frederick Douglass credited him 
as the originator of radical abolitionism, and his “Appeal” inspired some 
of the most influential members of the 20th century liberation movement. From Malcolm X’s militant approach
to Black resistance, to James Cone’s writing
on Black spirituality, Walker’s legacy remains
crucially important to the history of Black resistance movements— and their visions for the future.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: David Walker distributed his "Appeal to the Colored Citizens of the World" from the abolitionist hotbed of _______.
Options: A. Charleston, B. New York City, C. Boston, D. Phoenix
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Where did David Walker carefully stitch a pamphlet into the lining of a sailor's coat in 1830? Options: A. Wilmington, North Carolina, B. Boston Harbor, C. Charleston, D. A clothing store near the Boston Harbor Correct Option: D
Question 2: What was the name of the pamphlet that Walker wrote, which was considered one of the most dangerous documents in American history? Options: A. "Appeal to the Colored Citizens of the World", B. "The Abolitionist's Guide", C. "The Freedom Fighter's Manual", D. "The Black Liberation Pamphlet" Correct Option: A
Question 3: According to the text, what was the AME Church's approach to ending slavery compared to the mainstream movement? Options: A. The AME Church favored gradual change and avoided confrontation with slaveholders., B. The AME Church practiced a more radical brand of abolition., C. The AME Church had no approach to ending slavery., D. The AME Church was part of the mainstream movement. Correct Option: B
Question 4: How did David Walker help fund America's first Black-owned newspaper? Options: A. He wrote passionate articles and public speeches., B. He opened a clothing store and sold abolitionist literature., C. He contributed financially to the newspaper., D. He wrote a pamphlet that inspired others to fund the newspaper. Correct Option: C
Question 5: What was David Walker's stance on Black Americans emigrating to Africa? Options: A. He supported the idea of Black Americans emigrating to Africa., B. He opposed the idea of Black Americans emigrating to Africa., C. He had no stance on the issue., D. He suggested it as a viable option. Correct Option: B
Question 6: According to the text, what was the significance of David Walker's "Appeal to the Colored Citizens of the World"? Options: A. It was a call to arms against slave owners., B. It emphasized the importance of Black solidarity and connected American abolitionism with global movements for Black liberation., C. It criticized the Founding Fathers for their hypocrisy., D. All of the above. Correct Option: D
Question 7: How did the Southern officials respond to David Walker's pamphlet? Options: A. They praised him for his views on abolition., B. They ignored the pamphlet and continued to practice slavery., C. They placed a bounty on his head and cracked down on Black education., D. They banned the pamphlet but allowed it to be discussed in public. Correct Option: C
Question 8: What was the likely cause of David Walker's death in 1830? Options: A. Assassination, B. Tuberculosis, C. Drowning, D. Starvation Correct Option: B
Question 9: How did David Walker's message continue to resound after his death? Options: A. His associates declared him the victim of assassination and his message faded away., B. His message was forgotten and had no impact on future generations., C. Frederick Douglass credited him as the originator of radical abolitionism, and his "Appeal" inspired some of the most influential members of the 20th century liberation movement., D. None of the above. Correct Option: C
Question 10: What is the significance of David Walker's legacy in the history of Black resistance movements? Options: A. It is a reminder of the importance of gradual change and avoiding confrontation with slaveholders., B. It is a testament to the power of Black solidarity and the importance of connecting American abolitionism with global movements for Black liberation., C. It is a call to arms against slave owners., D. It is a critique of the Founding Fathers for their hypocrisy. Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is:

**Question 1: Where did David Walker carefully stitch a pamphlet into the lining of a sailor's coat in 1830? Options: A. Wilmington, North Carolina, B. Boston Harbor, C. Charleston, D. A clothing store near the Boston Harbor Correct Option: D**

This question is similar to the ground truth MCQ because it mentions the location where David Walker distributed his pamphlet, which is near the Boston Harbor. Although the question is phrased differently, the intent and content are similar.

However, a more accurate match would be a question that directly asks about the distribution location of the "Appeal to the Colored Citizens of the World" pamphlet. Unfortunately, such a question is not present among the generated MCQs.

But if I had to choose the most similar one, I would choose **Question 1**.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 4, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In 1830 at a clothing store
near the Boston Harbor, David Walker carefully stitched
a pamphlet into the lining of a sailor’s coat. The volume was thin enough
to be completely hidden, but its content was 
far from insubstantial. In fact, at the time, many members 
of the US government considered this pamphlet to be one 
of the most dangerous documents in American history. So to ensure this volume
reached his audience, Walker had to hide his work 
in the clothing of both willing co-conspirators 
and unknowing sailors; smuggling the pamphlet 
throughout the country. But what was this incendiary document? 
And who exactly was the man who wrote it? Son of an enslaved father
and a freedwoman, David Walker was born free 
in the late 18th century in Wilmington, North Carolina. From a young age, he sought to extend 
his freedom to all Black Americans, and after moving to Charleston
as a young man, he became closely involved with the
African Methodist Episcopal Church. At that time, the mainstream movement 
to end slavery was comprised of societies led by wealthy white men 
who favored gradual change and avoided confrontation
with slaveholders. But the AME Church practiced
a more radical brand of abolition. In 1822, AME leader Denmark Vesey
planned a major insurrection intended to violently liberate 
Charleston’s enslaved community and set the city ablaze. It’s unclear if Walker contributed
to Vesey’s plan, but he wasn’t among the many AME members
who were arrested and executed for this attempted rebellion. In 1825, Walker surfaced in Boston, where
he rejoined the fight against slavery. In addition to marrying 
fellow activist Eliza Butler and opening his clothing store, Walker helped fund America’s
first Black-owned newspaper. Is passionate articles and public speeches
sought to instill pride and camaraderie into those fighting for Black liberation. But to truly unite free 
and enslaved Black Americans, Walker would have to go beyond Boston. In 1829, he poured his ideas into the “Appeal to the Colored Citizens 
of the World.” This treatise was punctuated
with furious exclamation marks and emphasized the spiritual righteousness
of resistance. He described the suffering of enslaved
people in graphic detail to prove that the reality for Black Americans
was often “kill or be killed.” And given these circumstances, Walker staunchly defended 
the right to militant action. This wasn’t his only departure 
from moderate mainstream abolitionists. To stress the importance
of Black solidarity, Walker connected American abolitionism with global movements 
for Black liberation. He called for an international 
Black freedom struggle in an early display of what would come
to be called Pan-Africanism. But at the same time, 
he opposed the popular movement for Black Americans to emigrate to Africa. While the “Appeal” criticized 
the Founding Fathers for their hypocrisy, Walker insisted that Black people were
essential to the country’s creation, and had an undeniable right
to American citizenship. Walker suspected 
these incendiary arguments would make him a target for violence. But in spite of the danger, he continued 
using sailors to smuggle his work. The “Appeal” traveled down the coast 
into the hands of shopkeepers, church leaders, political organizers, 
and underground abolitionist networks. For these readers, Walker’s words
galvanized militant efforts to overthrow slave owners and its call to arms struck fear
into white officials. Police intercepted its delivery, and quarantined Black sailors
at Southern ports. The pamphlet inspired Louisiana 
to ban anti-slavery literature, and both North and South Carolina 
cracked down on Black education to prevent literacy 
among enslaved peoples. Southern officials even placed 
a bounty on Walker’s head worth the modern equivalent
of $322,000. But while friends urged him to flee,
Walker refused to abandon his cause. Tragically, his bravery 
couldn’t protect him from the deadliest disease of his time. In August 1830, Walker was found dead. And while his associates declared
him the victim of assassination, it’s now widely believed 
that he died from tuberculosis. Following his death, Walker's message
continued to resound. Frederick Douglass credited him 
as the originator of radical abolitionism, and his “Appeal” inspired some 
of the most influential members of the 20th century liberation movement. From Malcolm X’s militant approach
to Black resistance, to James Cone’s writing
on Black spirituality, Walker’s legacy remains
crucially important to the history of Black resistance movements— and their visions for the future.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The political backlash against Walker’s "Appeal" included which of the following legislative responses in the American South?
Options: A. Abolition of slavery, B. Anti-literacy laws, C. Fugitive Slave Act, D. Indentured Servitude Act
Correct Option: B

The AME Church had no approach to ending slavery., D. The AME Church was part of the mainstream movement. Correct Option: B
Question 4: How did David Walker help fund America's first Black-owned newspaper? Options: A. He wrote passionate articles and public speeches., B. He opened a clothing store and sold abolitionist literature., C. He contributed financially to the newspaper., D. He wrote a pamphlet that inspired others to fund the newspaper. Correct Option: C
Question 5: What was David Walker's stance on Black Americans emigrating to Africa? Options: A. He supported the idea of Black Americans emigrating to Africa., B. He opposed the idea of Black Americans emigrating to Africa., C. He had no stance on the issue., D. He suggested it as a viable option. Correct Option: B
Question 6: According to the text, what was the significance of David Walker's "Appeal to the Colored Citizens of the World"? Options: A. It was a call to arms against slave owners., B. It emphasized the importance of Black solidarity and connected American abolitionism with global movements for Black liberation., C. It criticized the Founding Fathers for their hypocrisy., D. All of the above. Correct Option: D
Question 7: How did the Southern officials respond to David Walker's pamphlet? Options: A. They praised him for his views on abolition., B.
