**Transcript**:
In the grasslands of Mauritania, a gazelle suffering from tuberculosis 
takes its last breath. Collapsing near a small pool, the animal’s corpse 
threatens to infect the water. But for the desert’s cleanup crew, 
this body isn’t a problem: it’s a feast. Weighing up to 10 kilograms and possessing a wingspan 
of nearly 3 meters, the lappet-faced vulture 
is the undisputed king of the carcass. This bird’s powerful beak and strong neck easily tear through tough hide 
and muscle tissue, opening entry points 
for weaker vultures to dig in. This colossal competition is too dangerous
for the tiny Egyptian vulture. With a wingspan of only 180 centimeters, this vulture migrated to Africa 
from his family nest in Portugal, using thermal updrafts to stay aloft 
for hours at a time. But upon arrival, he finds himself near 
the bottom of the pecking order. Fortunately, what he lacks in size, 
he makes up for in intelligence. A short distance away, 
he spots an unguarded ostrich nest, full of immense, but impenetrable eggs. Using a large rock, he smashes one open
for a well-earned meal— though he’ll circle back to the gazelle 
once the larger birds are gone. High above the commotion 
are Ruppell’s Griffon vultures. Soaring at an altitude 
of over 11,000 meters, these birds fly higher 
than any other animal. At this height, they can’t see 
individual carcasses. But the sight of their fellow vultures 
guides them to the feeding. Their featherless heads help them regulate the sudden rise in temperature 
as they descend— and keep them clean 
as they tear into the decaying gazelle. The carcass is stripped clean in hours, well before the rotting meat 
infects the water supply. And the tuberculosis doesn’t 
stand a chance at infecting the vultures. These birds have evolved the lowest 
gastric pH in the animal kingdom, allowing them to digest diseased 
carrion and waste without becoming sick. In fact, species like 
the mountain-dwelling bearded vulture have stomachs so acidic, they can digest most bones 
in just 24 hours. This adaptation helps smaller vultures 
supplement their diet with dung, while larger vultures can consume 
diseased meat up to 3 days old. Their acidic stomachs protect them 
from living animals too: their rancid vomit 
scares off most predators. These stomachs of steel are essential 
to removing pathogens like cholera, anthrax, and rabies 
from the African ecosystem. But while vultures can easily digest

alerting authorities to their location. One poisoned carcass can kill 
over 500 vultures. Today, more than 50% of all vulture 
species are endangered. In regions where vultures 
have gone extinct, corpses take three times longer to decay. These carcasses contaminate 
drinking water, while feral dogs and rats carry 
the diseases into human communities. The Asian and African Vulture Crisis 
has led to an epidemic of rabies in India, where infections kill roughly 
20,000 people each year. Fortunately, some communities have already
realized how important vultures are. Conservationists have successfully banned
drugs like Diclofenac, while other researchers are working 
to repopulate vulture communities through breeding programs. Some regions have even opened 
vulture restaurants where farmers safely dispose 
of drug-free livestock. With help, vultures will be able 
to continue their role conserving the health of our planet—
transforming death and decay into life.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Ruppell’s Griffon vultures can fly higher than any other animal. What altitude have they been recorded at?
Options: A. 11,000 meters, B. 2,000 meters, C. 7,000 meters, D. 5,000 meters
Correct Option: A

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 8, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Lord Sun dawns on the day called 7-Monkey, his fingers slowly spreading a rosy sheen that mixes softly with smoke rising 
from Tenochtitlan’s many hearth fires. The midwife, Xoquauhtli, 
has a difficult choice to make. A momentous shift from rainy season 
to dry season is underway. All summer, the gods have kept 
the people fed with corn, but the fertile summer months 
are disappearing. This day occurs during the festival 
that marks the shift between the summer season,
when the gods feed the people, and the winter season,
when the people feed the gods in return. Xoquauhtli owes a debt 
to her patron, Teteoinnan, the female warrior goddess 
at the center of this festival. Teteoinnan wages war both 
on women’s battlefields of birth and in men’s battles 
with Tenochtilan’s enemies. She must be kept happy 
or she will bring bad luck. The midwife should participate 
in the festival today, but one of her patients could 
go into labor any minute. Xoquauhtli decides to check 
on her patient first. The expecting mother hasn’t 
worked too hard, chewed gum, or lifted heavy things. Her family is taking good care of her. Surely Xoquauhtli can take a little time 
to honor her goddess. She leaves her apprentice in charge 
and heads to the center of the city. Along the way, she sees women sweeping
the roads and hanging gourds in preparation for the festival. Finally, she reaches the Great Pyramid. On top are two temples: the north, where rituals honor 
the rain god in the summer, and the south one is where rituals 
honor the war god in the winter. On the equinox, the sun rises 
between the two sides. The ceremony begins with a mock battle 
between the midwives and the other physicians. Xoquauhtli’s team battles heartily, 
throwing nochtles, marigolds, and balls made of reed and moss. They joke, call their rivals names, 
and laugh. But then, a girl comes running 
with a message for Xoquauhtli. Her patient is in labor! She hurries back to the house. All the old women 
from the extended family have already gathered for the birth— their experience is very valuable 
if anything goes wrong. She readies herself with a prayer praising
her most important tools, her fingers. Then she doses the patient with cihuapatli
to help expel the baby, massages her in the sweathouse, 
and rubs her stomach with tobacco. Offering Teteoinnan a short prayer, she urges her patient 
to act like a warrior. A strong baby girl slips 
into her waiting hands and the old women shout triumphant cries. Xoquauhtli takes a few drops of water 
from a jade bowl, breaths on them, and places them on the baby’s tiny tongue. She calls her a precious greenstone, 
a little warrior, and tells her how the Lord and Lady 
of the Ninth Sky breathed life into her, sending her 
to this place of burden and torment. She then turns to the new mother, 
praising her, telling her she acted like 
an eagle warrior, a jaguar warrior. By the time they finish, it’s late, 
and the flames of the fire have died down. Xoquauhtli piles the remaining hot coals 
in the center of the hearth, stoking them to keep them going. She lays the baby in a woven basket, 
head facing the warming fire. This will warm her tonalli, 
an important “soul” center in the body central to health and well-being. It’s almost midnight— 
if Xoquauhtli hurries, she can get back to the temple 
for the culmination of the festival. She makes her way to the city center, 
where a priest carries a woman on his back to the top of the pyramid. To begin the new season and feed the gods,
she will be beheaded, symbolizing how corn is cut in the fields. Afterward, she will be reborn 
as Lady Teteoinnan, and preside over the induction 
of new warriors.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Who is the midwife in this story and what did she do?
Options: A. Tenochtli, an experienced woman warrior who, when not attending to birthing mothers, battled opponents on the field of war., B. Xoquauhtli, an older woman, who attended both a sacrificial ritual and the birth of a baby girl., C. Luchadora, a young woman who kept herself fit for the rigors of childbirth by battling other wrestlers., D. Totoltin, an elderly lady who provided valued assistance during the birth, thereby saving the baby from death.
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the name of the midwife in the transcript? Options: A. Xoquauhtli, B. Teteoinnan, C. Lord Sun, D. Tenochtitlan Correct Option: A
Question 2: What is the significance of the festival that marks the shift between the summer and winter seasons? Options: A. It celebrates the birth of the midwife's child, B. It honors the gods who provide food for the people, C. It marks the beginning of a new season and the feeding of the gods, D. It is a celebration of the harvest season Correct Option: C
Question 3: What is the role of Teteoinnan, the female warrior goddess, in the festival? Options: A. She is the patron of the midwife, B. She is the one who will be beheaded and reborn as Lady Teteoinnan, C. She is the rain god in the summer and the war god in the winter, D. She is the one who will be reborn as a new warrior Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is the name of the ritual that Xoquauhtli's team participates in during the festival? Options: A. A mock battle between the midwives and the physicians, B. A ceremony to honor the rain god in the summer, C. A ceremony to honor the war god in the winter, D. A celebration of the harvest season Correct Option: A
Question 5: What is the significance of the baby's tonalli in the body? Options: A. It is an important "soul" center in the body central to health and well-being, B. It is a center of energy in the body, C. It is a center of strength in the body, D. It is a center of weakness in the body Correct Option: A
Question 6: What is the significance of the priest carrying a woman on his back to the top of the pyramid during the festival? Options: A. It is a symbol of the midwife's power and strength, B. It is a symbol of the beginning of a new season and the feeding of the gods, C. It is a celebration of the harvest season, D. It is a celebration of the birth of the midwife's child Correct Option: B
Question 7: What is the purpose of the priest carrying the woman on his back to the top of the pyramid during the festival? Options: A. To begin the new season and feed the gods, B. To celebrate the harvest season, C. To celebrate the birth of the midwife's child, D. To honor the rain god in the summer Correct Option: A
Question 8: What is the significance of the woman being beheaded and reborn as Lady Teteoinnan during the festival? Options: A. It is a symbol of the midwife's power and strength, B. It is a symbol of the beginning of a new season and the feeding of the gods, C. It is a celebration of the harvest season, D. It is a celebration of the birth of the midwife's child Correct Option: B
Question 9: What is the role of the new mother in the ritual of the baby's birth? Options: A. She is the one who acts like an eagle warrior and a jaguar warrior, B. She is the one who is being beheaded and reborn as Lady Teteoinnan, C. She is the one who is carrying the baby, D. She is the one who is being carried on the priest's back Correct Option: A
Question 10: What is the purpose of the priest carrying the woman on his back to the top of the pyramid during the festival, and what happens to her afterward? Options: A. To begin the new season and feed the gods, and she will be reborn as Lady Teteoinnan and preside over the induction of new warriors, B. To celebrate the harvest season and she will be reborn as a new warrior, C. To celebrate the birth of the midwife's child and she will be reborn as Lady Teteoinnan, D. To honor the rain god in the summer and she will be reborn as a new warrior Correct Option: A


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The most similar generated MCQ to the ground truth MCQ is Question 1. 

Although Question 1 does not perfectly match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question content and options, it is the closest match among the provided generated MCQs. The ground truth MCQ asks about the midwife's identity and actions, while Question 1 only asks about the midwife's name. However, Question 1's correct option (A. Xoquauhtli) aligns with the correct option of the ground truth MCQ (B. Xoquauhtli, an older woman, who attended both a sacrificial ritual and the birth of a baby girl.).

Other generated MCQs may touch on aspects of the midwife's actions or the festival, but they do not directly address the midwife's identity and actions as the ground truth MCQ does. Therefore, Question 1 is the most similar generated MCQ, despite its limitations.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 8, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Lord Sun dawns on the day called 7-Monkey, his fingers slowly spreading a rosy sheen that mixes softly with smoke rising 
from Tenochtitlan’s many hearth fires. The midwife, Xoquauhtli, 
has a difficult choice to make. A momentous shift from rainy season 
to dry season is underway. All summer, the gods have kept 
the people fed with corn, but the fertile summer months 
are disappearing. This day occurs during the festival 
that marks the shift between the summer season,
when the gods feed the people, and the winter season,
when the people feed the gods in return. Xoquauhtli owes a debt 
to her patron, Teteoinnan, the female warrior goddess 
at the center of this festival. Teteoinnan wages war both 
on women’s battlefields of birth and in men’s battles 
with Tenochtilan’s enemies. She must be kept happy 
or she will bring bad luck. The midwife should participate 
in the festival today, but one of her patients could 
go into labor any minute. Xoquauhtli decides to check 
on her patient first. The expecting mother hasn’t 
worked too hard, chewed gum, or lifted heavy things. Her family is taking good care of her. Surely Xoquauhtli can take a little time 
to honor her goddess. She leaves her apprentice in charge 
and heads to the center of the city. Along the way, she sees women sweeping
the roads and hanging gourds in preparation for the festival. Finally, she reaches the Great Pyramid. On top are two temples: the north, where rituals honor 
the rain god in the summer, and the south one is where rituals 
honor the war god in the winter. On the equinox, the sun rises 
between the two sides. The ceremony begins with a mock battle 
between the midwives and the other physicians. Xoquauhtli’s team battles heartily, 
throwing nochtles, marigolds, and balls made of reed and moss. They joke, call their rivals names, 
and laugh. But then, a girl comes running 
with a message for Xoquauhtli. Her patient is in labor! She hurries back to the house. All the old women 
from the extended family have already gathered for the birth— their experience is very valuable 
if anything goes wrong. She readies herself with a prayer praising
her most important tools, her fingers. Then she doses the patient with cihuapatli
to help expel the baby, massages her in the sweathouse, 
and rubs her stomach with tobacco. Offering Teteoinnan a short prayer, she urges her patient 
to act like a warrior. A strong baby girl slips 
into her waiting hands and the old women shout triumphant cries. Xoquauhtli takes a few drops of water 
from a jade bowl, breaths on them, and places them on the baby’s tiny tongue. She calls her a precious greenstone, 
a little warrior, and tells her how the Lord and Lady 
of the Ninth Sky breathed life into her, sending her 
to this place of burden and torment. She then turns to the new mother, 
praising her, telling her she acted like 
an eagle warrior, a jaguar warrior. By the time they finish, it’s late, 
and the flames of the fire have died down. Xoquauhtli piles the remaining hot coals 
in the center of the hearth, stoking them to keep them going. She lays the baby in a woven basket, 
head facing the warming fire. This will warm her tonalli, 
an important “soul” center in the body central to health and well-being. It’s almost midnight— 
if Xoquauhtli hurries, she can get back to the temple 
for the culmination of the festival. She makes her way to the city center, 
where a priest carries a woman on his back to the top of the pyramid. To begin the new season and feed the gods,
she will be beheaded, symbolizing how corn is cut in the fields. Afterward, she will be reborn 
as Lady Teteoinnan, and preside over the induction 
of new warriors.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What happened in the birth?
Options: A. All the old women assisting at the birth shouted out cries of victory because the mother had successfully captured her new baby., B. The midwife prayed to her fingers, massaged the mother’s belly with tobacco, and blessed the baby’s first sip of water., C. After the birth, the midwife told the new baby girl that she was a little warrior and then praised her mother for acting like an eagle and a jaguar warrior., D. All of the above
Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 8, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Lord Sun dawns on the day called 7-Monkey, his fingers slowly spreading a rosy sheen that mixes softly with smoke rising 
from Tenochtitlan’s many hearth fires. The midwife, Xoquauhtli, 
has a difficult choice to make. A momentous shift from rainy season 
to dry season is underway. All summer, the gods have kept 
the people fed with corn, but the fertile summer months 
are disappearing. This day occurs during the festival 
that marks the shift between the summer season,
when the gods feed the people, and the winter season,
when the people feed the gods in return. Xoquauhtli owes a debt 
to her patron, Teteoinnan, the female warrior goddess 
at the center of this festival. Teteoinnan wages war both 
on women’s battlefields of birth and in men’s battles 
with Tenochtilan’s enemies. She must be kept happy 
or she will bring bad luck. The midwife should participate 
in the festival today, but one of her patients could 
go into labor any minute. Xoquauhtli decides to check 
on her patient first. The expecting mother hasn’t 
worked too hard, chewed gum, or lifted heavy things. Her family is taking good care of her. Surely Xoquauhtli can take a little time 
to honor her goddess. She leaves her apprentice in charge 
and heads to the center of the city. Along the way, she sees women sweeping
the roads and hanging gourds in preparation for the festival. Finally, she reaches the Great Pyramid. On top are two temples: the north, where rituals honor 
the rain god in the summer, and the south one is where rituals 
honor the war god in the winter. On the equinox, the sun rises 
between the two sides. The ceremony begins with a mock battle 
between the midwives and the other physicians. Xoquauhtli’s team battles heartily, 
throwing nochtles, marigolds, and balls made of reed and moss. They joke, call their rivals names, 
and laugh. But then, a girl comes running 
with a message for Xoquauhtli. Her patient is in labor! She hurries back to the house. All the old women 
from the extended family have already gathered for the birth— their experience is very valuable 
if anything goes wrong. She readies herself with a prayer praising
her most important tools, her fingers. Then she doses the patient with cihuapatli
to help expel the baby, massages her in the sweathouse, 
and rubs her stomach with tobacco. Offering Teteoinnan a short prayer, she urges her patient 
to act like a warrior. A strong baby girl slips 
into her waiting hands and the old women shout triumphant cries. Xoquauhtli takes a few drops of water 
from a jade bowl, breaths on them, and places them on the baby’s tiny tongue. She calls her a precious greenstone, 
a little warrior, and tells her how the Lord and Lady 
of the Ninth Sky breathed life into her, sending her 
to this place of burden and torment. She then turns to the new mother, 
praising her, telling her she acted like 
an eagle warrior, a jaguar warrior. By the time they finish, it’s late, 
and the flames of the fire have died down. Xoquauhtli piles the remaining hot coals 
in the center of the hearth, stoking them to keep them going. She lays the baby in a woven basket, 
head facing the warming fire. This will warm her tonalli, 
an important “soul” center in the body central to health and well-being. It’s almost midnight— 
if Xoquauhtli hurries, she can get back to the temple 
for the culmination of the festival. She makes her way to the city center, 
where a priest carries a woman on his back to the top of the pyramid. To begin the new season and feed the gods,
she will be beheaded, symbolizing how corn is cut in the fields. Afterward, she will be reborn 
as Lady Teteoinnan, and preside over the induction 
of new warriors.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What festival did the midwife attend?
Options: A. “The Gathering of Grains,” Tortaliztli, which honored the bountiful harvest of wheat, soy, apples and mangos soon to be gathered from the fields., B. “The Victory of War,” Yautiliztli, which blessed the warriors and prayed for their success in conquering new cities., C. “Sweeping the Roads,” Ochpaniztli, which marked the shift in seasons from summer’s wet time of growing corn to winter’s dry time of war., D. “Honoring the Sun’s Light,” Tititl, which marked the equinox when the Sun’s light began to slowly diminish, eventually leaving all in darkness.
Correct Option: C

**Transcript**:
Lord Sun dawns on the day called 7-Monkey, his fingers slowly spreading a rosy sheen that mixes softly with smoke rising 
from Tenochtitlan’s many hearth fires. The midwife, Xoquauhtli, 
has a difficult choice to make. A momentous shift from rainy season 
to dry season is underway. All summer, the gods have kept 
the people fed with corn, but the fertile summer months 
are disappearing. This day occurs during the festival 
that marks the shift between the summer season,
when the gods feed the people, and the winter season,
when the people feed the gods in return. Xoquauhtli owes a debt 
to her patron, Teteoinnan, the female warrior goddess 
at the center of this festival. Teteoinnan wages war both 
on women’s battlefields of birth and in men’s battles 
with Tenochtilan’s enemies. She must be kept happy 
or she will bring bad luck. The midwife should participate 
in the festival today, but one of her patients could 
go into labor any minute. Xoquauhtli decides to check 
on her patient first. The expecting mother hasn’t 
worked too hard, chewed gum, or lifted heavy things. Her family is taking good care of her. Surely Xoquauhtli can take a little time 
to honor her goddess. She leaves her apprentice in charge 
and heads to the center of the city. Along the way, she sees women sweeping
the roads and hanging gourds in preparation for the festival. Finally, she reaches the Great Pyramid. On top are two temples: the north, where rituals honor 
the rain god in the summer, and the south one is where rituals 
honor the war god in the winter. On the equinox, the sun rises 
between the two sides. The ceremony begins with a mock battle 
between the midwives and the other physicians. Xoquauhtli’s team battles heartily, 
throwing nochtles, marigolds, and balls made of reed and moss. They joke, call their rivals names, 
and laugh. But then, a girl comes running 
with a message for Xoquauhtli. Her patient is in labor! She hurries back to the house. All the old women 
from the extended family have already gathered for the birth— their experience is very valuable 
if anything goes wrong. She readies herself with a prayer praising
her most important tools, her fingers. Then she doses the patient with cihuapatli
to help expel the baby, massages her in the sweathouse, 
and rubs her stomach with tobacco. Offering Teteoinnan a short prayer, she urges her patient 
to act like a warrior. A strong baby girl slips 
into her waiting hands and the old women shout triumphant cries. Xoquauhtli takes a few drops of water 
from a jade bowl, breaths on them, and places them on the baby’s tiny tongue. She calls her a precious greenstone, 
a little warrior, and tells her how the Lord and Lady 
of the Ninth Sky breathed life into her, sending her 
to this place of burden and torment. She then turns to the new mother, 
praising her, telling her she acted like 
an eagle warrior, a jaguar warrior. By the time they finish, it’s late, 
and the flames of the fire have died down. Xoquauhtli piles the remaining hot coals 
in the center of the hearth, stoking them to keep them going. She lays the baby in a woven basket, 
head facing the warming fire. This will warm her tonalli, 
an important “soul” center in the body central to health and well-being. It’s almost midnight— 
if Xoquauhtli hurries, she can get back to the temple 
for the culmination of the festival. She makes her way to the city center, 
where a priest carries a woman on his back to the top of the pyramid. To begin the new season and feed the gods,
she will be beheaded, symbolizing how corn is cut in the fields. Afterward, she will be reborn 
as Lady Teteoinnan, and preside over the induction 
of new warriors.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What did the midwife do at the festival?
Options: A. a. Watched the sacrifice of a woman, which transformed her into the midwife’s patroness, the goddess Teteoinnan., B. b. Swept the streets and hung gourds and then went to watch the induction of new eagle and jaguar warriors., C. c. Took part in a mock, ritual battle by throwing nochtles (cactus fruit) and reed balls at other midwives and physicians., D. Both a and c.
Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 8, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Lord Sun dawns on the day called 7-Monkey, his fingers slowly spreading a rosy sheen that mixes softly with smoke rising 
from Tenochtitlan’s many hearth fires. The midwife, Xoquauhtli, 
has a difficult choice to make. A momentous shift from rainy season 
to dry season is underway. All summer, the gods have kept 
the people fed with corn, but the fertile summer months 
are disappearing. This day occurs during the festival 
that marks the shift between the summer season,
when the gods feed the people, and the winter season,
when the people feed the gods in return. Xoquauhtli owes a debt 
to her patron, Teteoinnan, the female warrior goddess 
at the center of this festival. Teteoinnan wages war both 
on women’s battlefields of birth and in men’s battles 
with Tenochtilan’s enemies. She must be kept happy 
or she will bring bad luck. The midwife should participate 
in the festival today, but one of her patients could 
go into labor any minute. Xoquauhtli decides to check 
on her patient first. The expecting mother hasn’t 
worked too hard, chewed gum, or lifted heavy things. Her family is taking good care of her. Surely Xoquauhtli can take a little time 
to honor her goddess. She leaves her apprentice in charge 
and heads to the center of the city. Along the way, she sees women sweeping
the roads and hanging gourds in preparation for the festival. Finally, she reaches the Great Pyramid. On top are two temples: the north, where rituals honor 
the rain god in the summer, and the south one is where rituals 
honor the war god in the winter. On the equinox, the sun rises 
between the two sides. The ceremony begins with a mock battle 
between the midwives and the other physicians. Xoquauhtli’s team battles heartily, 
throwing nochtles, marigolds, and balls made of reed and moss. They joke, call their rivals names, 
and laugh. But then, a girl comes running 
with a message for Xoquauhtli. Her patient is in labor! She hurries back to the house. All the old women 
from the extended family have already gathered for the birth— their experience is very valuable 
if anything goes wrong. She readies herself with a prayer praising
her most important tools, her fingers. Then she doses the patient with cihuapatli
to help expel the baby, massages her in the sweathouse, 
and rubs her stomach with tobacco. Offering Teteoinnan a short prayer, she urges her patient 
to act like a warrior. A strong baby girl slips 
into her waiting hands and the old women shout triumphant cries. Xoquauhtli takes a few drops of water 
from a jade bowl, breaths on them, and places them on the baby’s tiny tongue. She calls her a precious greenstone, 
a little warrior, and tells her how the Lord and Lady 
of the Ninth Sky breathed life into her, sending her 
to this place of burden and torment. She then turns to the new mother, 
praising her, telling her she acted like 
an eagle warrior, a jaguar warrior. By the time they finish, it’s late, 
and the flames of the fire have died down. Xoquauhtli piles the remaining hot coals 
in the center of the hearth, stoking them to keep them going. She lays the baby in a woven basket, 
head facing the warming fire. This will warm her tonalli, 
an important “soul” center in the body central to health and well-being. It’s almost midnight— 
if Xoquauhtli hurries, she can get back to the temple 
for the culmination of the festival. She makes her way to the city center, 
where a priest carries a woman on his back to the top of the pyramid. To begin the new season and feed the gods,
she will be beheaded, symbolizing how corn is cut in the fields. Afterward, she will be reborn 
as Lady Teteoinnan, and preside over the induction 
of new warriors.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Who was the midwife’s patroness?
Options: A. Teteoinnan, a warrior goddess who attended to both babies preparing for new lives and warriors preparing for new battles., B. Xollonantli, a canine goddess whose loyalty to the birthing mother was so strong that she would assure a healthy child and even lick the new baby clean., C. Coyolxauhqui, a moon goddess whose decapitation symbolized both the phases, of the moon and pregnancy., D. Tonacacihuatl, a goddess of abundance, who governed procreation and watched over newly planted bean seeds.
Correct Option: A

Question 1: What is the name of the midwife in the transcript? Options: A. Xoquauhtli, B. Teteoinnan, C. Lord Sun, D. Tenochtitlan Correct Option: A
Question 2: What is the significance of the festival that marks the shift between the summer and winter seasons? Options: A. It celebrates the birth of the midwife's child, B. It honors the gods who provide food for the people, C. It marks the beginning of a new season and the feeding of the gods, D. It is a celebration of the harvest season Correct Option: C
Question 3: What is the role of Teteoinnan, the female warrior goddess, in the festival? Options: A. She is the patron of the midwife, B. She is the one who will be beheaded and reborn as Lady Teteoinnan, C. She is the rain god in the summer and the war god in the winter, D. She is the one who will be reborn as a new warrior Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is the name of the ritual that Xoquauhtli's team participates in during the festival? Options: A. A mock battle between the midwives and the physicians, B. A ceremony to honor the rain god in the summer, C. A ceremony to honor the war god in the winter, D. A celebration of the harvest season Correct Option: A
Question 5: What is the significance of the baby's tonalli in the body? Options: A. It is an important "soul" center in the body central to health and well-being, B. It is a center of energy in the body, C. It is a center of strength in the body, D. It is a center of weakness in the body Correct Option: A
Question 6: What is the significance of the priest carrying a woman on his back to the top of the pyramid during the festival? Options: A. It is a symbol of the midwife's power and strength, B. It is a symbol of the beginning of a new season and the feeding of the gods, C. It is a celebration of the harvest season, D. It is a celebration of the birth of the midwife's child Correct Option: B
Question 7: What is the purpose of the priest carrying the woman on his back to the top of the pyramid during the festival? Options: A. To begin the new season and feed the gods, B. To celebrate the harvest season, C. To celebrate the birth of the midwife's child, D. To honor the rain god in the summer Correct Option: A
Question 8: What is the significance of the woman being beheaded and reborn as Lady Teteoinnan during the festival? Options: A. It is a symbol of the midwife's power and strength, B. It is a symbol of the beginning of a new season and the feeding of the gods, C. It is a celebration of the harvest season, D. It is a celebration of the birth of the midwife's child Correct Option: B
Question 9: What is the role of the new mother in the ritual of the baby's birth? Options: A. She is the one who acts like an eagle warrior and a jaguar warrior, B. She is the one who is being beheaded and reborn as Lady Teteoinnan, C. She is the one who is carrying the baby, D. She is the one who is being carried on the priest's back Correct Option: A
Question 10: What is the purpose of the priest carrying the woman on his back to the top of the pyramid during the festival, and what happens to her afterward? Options: A. To begin the new season and feed the gods, and she will be reborn as Lady Teteoinnan and preside over the induction of new warriors, B. To celebrate the harvest season and she will be reborn as a new warrior, C. To celebrate the birth of the midwife's child and she will be reborn as Lady Teteoinnan, D. To honor the rain god in the summer and she will be reborn as a new warrior Correct Option: A


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 3. 

Although the ground truth MCQ specifically asks about the midwife's patroness, and Question 3 asks about the role of Teteoinnan in the festival, option A in Question 3 states that Teteoinnan is the patron of the midwife, which matches the content of the ground truth MCQ. However, it's worth noting that the question intent is not an exact match.

A more ideal match would be a generated MCQ that directly asks about the midwife's patroness, but since that is not available, Question 3 is the closest match based on the content and options provided.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 9, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Transcriber: TED Translators Admin
Reviewer: Mirjana Čutura About 10,000 years ago,
humans began to farm. This agricultural revolution
was a turning point in our history that enabled people to settle,
build and create. In short, agriculture
enabled the existence of civilization. Today, approximately 40 percent
of our planet is farmland. Spread all over the world, these agricultural lands
are the pieces to a global puzzle we are all facing: in the future, how can we feed
every member of a growing population a healthy diet? Meeting this goal will require nothing short of a second
agricultural revolution. The first agricultural revolution was characterized
by expansion and exploitation, feeding people at the expense
of forests, wildlife and water and destabilizing the climate
in the process. That's not an option the next time around. Agriculture depends on a stable climate with predictable seasons
and weather patterns. This means we can't keep
expanding our agricultural lands, because doing so will undermine
the environmental conditions that make agriculture possible
in the first place. Instead, the next agricultural revolution will have to increase the output
of our existing farmland for the long term while protecting biodiversity,
conserving water and reducing pollution
and greenhouse gas emissions. So what will the future farms look like? This drone is part of a fleet
that monitors the crops below. The farm may look haphazard but is a delicately engineered
use of the land that intertwines crops and livestock
with wild habitats. Conventional farming methods
cleared large swathes of land and planted them with a single crop, eradicating wildlife and emitting huge amounts
of greenhouse gases in the process. This approach aims to correct that damage. Meanwhile, moving among the crops, teams of field robots
apply fertilizer in targeted doses. Inside the soil, hundreds of sensors gather data
on nutrients and water levels. This information reduces
unnecessary water use and tells farmers where they should apply
more and less fertilizer instead of causing pollution
by showering it across the whole farm. But the farms of the future
won't be all sensors and robots. These technologies are designed
to help us produce food in a way that works with the environment rather than against it, taking into account
the nuances of local ecosystems. Lower-cost agricultural practices
can also serve those same goals and are much more accessible
to many farmers. In fact, many such practices
are already in use today and stand to have
an increasingly large impact as more farmers adopt them. In Costa Rica, farmers have intertwined farmland
with tropical habitat so successfully that they have significantly contributed
to doubling the country's forest cover. This provides food
and habitat for wildlife as well as natural pollination
and pest control from the birds and insects
these farms attract, producing food while restoring the planet. In the United States, ranchers are raising cattle
on grasslands composed of native species, generating a valuable protein source using production methods that store carbon
and protect biodiversity. In Bangladesh, Cambodia and Nepal, new approaches to rice production may dramatically decrease
greenhouse gas emissions in the future. Rice is a staple food
for three billion people and the main source of livelihood
for millions of households. More than 90 percent of rice
is grown in flooded paddies, which use a lot of water and release 11 percent
of annual methane emissions, which accounts for one to two percent of total annual greenhouse gas
emissions globally. By experimenting with new strains of rice, irrigating less and adopting less labor-intensive
ways of planting seeds, farmers in these countries have already increased
their incomes and crop yields while cutting down
on greenhouse gas emissions. In Zambia, numerous organizations
are investing in locally specific methods to improve crop production,
reduce forest loss and improve livelihoods for local farmers. These efforts are projected
to increase crop yield by almost a quarter
over the next few decades. If combined with methods
to combat deforestation in the region, they could move the country toward a resilient, climate-focused
agricultural sector. And in India, where up to 40 percent
of post-harvest food is lost or wasted due to poor infrastructure, farmers have already started to implement
solar-powered cold storage capsules that help thousands of rural farmers
preserve their produce and become a viable part
of the supply chain. It will take all of these methods, from the most high-tech
to the lowest-cost, to revolutionize farming. High-tech interventions stand to amplify climate- and conservation-oriented
approaches to farming, and large producers will need to invest
in implementing these technologies. Meanwhile, we'll have to expand access
to the lower-cost methods for smaller-scale farmers. This vision of future farming
will also require a global shift toward more plant-based diets and huge reductions
in food loss and waste, both of which will reduce
pressure on the land and allow farmers to do more
with what they have available. If we optimize food production,
both on land and sea, we can feed humanity within the environmental
limits of the earth, but there's a very small margin of error, and it will take unprecedented
global cooperation and coordination of the agricultural
lands we have today.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How long ago did humans begin to farm?
Options: A. More than 50,000 years ago, B. About 10,000 years ago, C. About 800 years ago, D. Less than 3,000 years ago
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the primary outcome of the first agricultural revolution? Options: A. The expansion of farmland led to an increase in greenhouse gas emissions., B. The development of new farming techniques led to a significant decrease in crop yields., C. The first agricultural revolution enabled the existence of civilization by providing a stable food source., D. The first agricultural revolution led to a significant decrease in forest cover. Correct Option: C
Question 2: What is the main goal of the next agricultural revolution? Options: A. To increase the output of existing farmland while protecting biodiversity and reducing pollution., B. To expand farmland at the expense of forests and wildlife and water., C. To develop new farming techniques that reduce crop yields., D. To decrease greenhouse gas emissions by reducing food production. Correct Option: A
Question 3: How can farmers in the future use drones to monitor crops? Options: A. By planting multiple crops in the same field., B. By using targeted doses of fertilizer and monitoring soil nutrients and water levels., C. By clearing large swathes of land and planting a single crop., D. By using high-tech interventions to amplify climate- and conservation-oriented approaches to farming. Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is the significance of the increase in forest cover in Costa Rica? Options: A. It has led to a significant decrease in greenhouse gas emissions., B. It has provided food and habitat for wildlife as well as natural pollination and pest control., C. It has led to a significant increase in crop yields., D. It has led to a significant decrease in forest biodiversity. Correct Option: B
Question 5: What is the main advantage of using solar-powered cold storage capsules in India? Options: A. It has led to a significant increase in crop yields., B. It has helped thousands of rural farmers preserve their produce and become a viable part of the supply chain., C. It has led to a significant decrease in greenhouse gas emissions., D. It has led to a significant decrease in food loss and waste. Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is the projected impact of locally specific methods to improve crop production in Zambia? Options: A. It will lead to a significant decrease in crop yields., B. It will increase crop yield by almost a quarter over the next few decades., C. It will lead to a significant increase in greenhouse gas emissions., D. It will lead to a significant decrease in forest cover. Correct Option: B
Question 7: What is the main challenge of feeding humanity within the environmental limits of the earth? Options: A. It will require a significant decrease in food production., B. It will require a global shift toward more plant-based diets and huge reductions in food loss and waste., C. It will require a significant increase in greenhouse gas emissions., D. It will require a significant decrease in forest cover. Correct Option: B
Question 8: What is the significance of the development of new strains of rice in Bangladesh, Cambodia, and Nepal? Options: A. It has led to a significant increase in greenhouse gas emissions., B. It has increased incomes and crop yields while cutting down on greenhouse gas emissions., C. It has led to a significant decrease in forest cover., D. It has led to a significant decrease in crop yields. Correct Option: B
Question 9: What is the main advantage of using locally specific methods to improve crop production in Zambia? Options: A. It will lead to a significant increase in greenhouse gas emissions., B. It will increase crop yield by almost a quarter over the next few decades., C. It will lead to a significant decrease in food loss and waste., D. It will lead to a significant decrease in forest cover. Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is the main goal of the vision of future farming? Options: A. To expand farmland at the expense of forests, wildlife, and water., B. To increase the output of existing farmland while protecting biodiversity and reducing pollution., C. To develop new farming techniques that reduce crop yields., D. To decrease greenhouse gas emissions by reducing food production. Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
None of the generated MCQs match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, options, and content. The ground truth MCQ asks about the time when humans began to farm, while the generated MCQs cover various other topics related to agriculture and farming.

However, if I had to choose the most similar generated MCQ based on the topic of agriculture and farming, I would say that Question 1 is the closest match. But it's still not similar to the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, options, and content.

Therefore, I would say that there is no matching generated MCQ for the given ground truth MCQ.

**Transcript**:
Transcriber: TED Translators Admin
Reviewer: Mirjana Čutura About 10,000 years ago,
humans began to farm. This agricultural revolution
was a turning point in our history that enabled people to settle,
build and create. In short, agriculture
enabled the existence of civilization. Today, approximately 40 percent
of our planet is farmland. Spread all over the world, these agricultural lands
are the pieces to a global puzzle we are all facing: in the future, how can we feed
every member of a growing population a healthy diet? Meeting this goal will require nothing short of a second
agricultural revolution. The first agricultural revolution was characterized
by expansion and exploitation, feeding people at the expense
of forests, wildlife and water and destabilizing the climate
in the process. That's not an option the next time around. Agriculture depends on a stable climate with predictable seasons
and weather patterns. This means we can't keep
expanding our agricultural lands, because doing so will undermine
the environmental conditions that make agriculture possible
in the first place. Instead, the next agricultural revolution will have to increase the output
of our existing farmland for the long term while protecting biodiversity,
conserving water and reducing pollution
and greenhouse gas emissions. So what will the future farms look like? This drone is part of a fleet
that monitors the crops below. The farm may look haphazard but is a delicately engineered
use of the land that intertwines crops and livestock
with wild habitats. Conventional farming methods
cleared large swathes of land and planted them with a single crop, eradicating wildlife and emitting huge amounts
of greenhouse gases in the process. This approach aims to correct that damage. Meanwhile, moving among the crops, teams of field robots
apply fertilizer in targeted doses. Inside the soil, hundreds of sensors gather data
on nutrients and water levels. This information reduces
unnecessary water use and tells farmers where they should apply
more and less fertilizer instead of causing pollution
by showering it across the whole farm. But the farms of the future
won't be all sensors and robots. These technologies are designed
to help us produce food in a way that works with the environment rather than against it, taking into account
the nuances of local ecosystems. Lower-cost agricultural practices
can also serve those same goals and are much more accessible
to many farmers. In fact, many such practices
are already in use today and stand to have
an increasingly large impact as more farmers adopt them. In Costa Rica, farmers have intertwined farmland
with tropical habitat so successfully that they have significantly contributed
to doubling the country's forest cover. This provides food
and habitat for wildlife as well as natural pollination
and pest control from the birds and insects
these farms attract, producing food while restoring the planet. In the United States, ranchers are raising cattle
on grasslands composed of native species, generating a valuable protein source using production methods that store carbon
and protect biodiversity. In Bangladesh, Cambodia and Nepal, new approaches to rice production may dramatically decrease
greenhouse gas emissions in the future. Rice is a staple food

to the lowest-cost, to revolutionize farming. High-tech interventions stand to amplify climate- and conservation-oriented
approaches to farming, and large producers will need to invest
in implementing these technologies. Meanwhile, we'll have to expand access

will also require a global shift toward more plant-based diets and huge reductions

both on land and sea, we can feed humanity within the environmental
limits of the earth, but there's a very small margin of error, and it will take unprecedented
global cooperation and coordination of the agricultural
lands we have today.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What are some characteristics of the first agricultural revolution?
Options: A. It was characterized by expansion and exploitation, B. It was characterized by the use of windmills and solar power, C. It was characterized by the use of sensors and robots, D. None of the above
Correct Option: A

A more suitable match would be a generated MCQ that explicitly mentions the characteristics of the first agricultural revolution, such as expansion and exploitation. Unfortunately, none of the generated MCQs perfectly match the ground truth MCQ.

If I had to choose an index, I would say that the most similar generated MCQ is not explicitly listed, but Question 2 is the closest. Therefore, the index would be 2.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 9, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Transcriber: TED Translators Admin
Reviewer: Mirjana Čutura About 10,000 years ago,
humans began to farm. This agricultural revolution
was a turning point in our history that enabled people to settle,
build and create. In short, agriculture
enabled the existence of civilization. Today, approximately 40 percent
of our planet is farmland. Spread all over the world, these agricultural lands
are the pieces to a global puzzle we are all facing: in the future, how can we feed
every member of a growing population a healthy diet? Meeting this goal will require nothing short of a second
agricultural revolution. The first agricultural revolution was characterized
by expansion and exploitation, feeding people at the expense
of forests, wildlife and water and destabilizing the climate
in the process. That's not an option the next time around. Agriculture depends on a stable climate with predictable seasons
and weather patterns. This means we can't keep
expanding our agricultural lands, because doing so will undermine
the environmental conditions that make agriculture possible
in the first place. Instead, the next agricultural revolution will have to increase the output
of our existing farmland for the long term while protecting biodiversity,
conserving water and reducing pollution
and greenhouse gas emissions. So what will the future farms look like? This drone is part of a fleet
that monitors the crops below. The farm may look haphazard but is a delicately engineered
use of the land that intertwines crops and livestock
with wild habitats. Conventional farming methods
cleared large swathes of land and planted them with a single crop, eradicating wildlife and emitting huge amounts
of greenhouse gases in the process. This approach aims to correct that damage. Meanwhile, moving among the crops, teams of field robots
apply fertilizer in targeted doses. Inside the soil, hundreds of sensors gather data
on nutrients and water levels. This information reduces
unnecessary water use and tells farmers where they should apply
more and less fertilizer instead of causing pollution
by showering it across the whole farm. But the farms of the future
won't be all sensors and robots. These technologies are designed
to help us produce food in a way that works with the environment rather than against it, taking into account
the nuances of local ecosystems. Lower-cost agricultural practices
can also serve those same goals and are much more accessible
to many farmers. In fact, many such practices
are already in use today and stand to have
an increasingly large impact as more farmers adopt them. In Costa Rica, farmers have intertwined farmland
with tropical habitat so successfully that they have significantly contributed
to doubling the country's forest cover. This provides food
and habitat for wildlife as well as natural pollination
and pest control from the birds and insects
these farms attract, producing food while restoring the planet. In the United States, ranchers are raising cattle
on grasslands composed of native species, generating a valuable protein source using production methods that store carbon
and protect biodiversity. In Bangladesh, Cambodia and Nepal, new approaches to rice production may dramatically decrease
greenhouse gas emissions in the future. Rice is a staple food
for three billion people and the main source of livelihood
for millions of households. More than 90 percent of rice
is grown in flooded paddies, which use a lot of water and release 11 percent
of annual methane emissions, which accounts for one to two percent of total annual greenhouse gas
emissions globally. By experimenting with new strains of rice, irrigating less and adopting less labor-intensive
ways of planting seeds, farmers in these countries have already increased
their incomes and crop yields while cutting down
on greenhouse gas emissions. In Zambia, numerous organizations
are investing in locally specific methods to improve crop production,
reduce forest loss and improve livelihoods for local farmers. These efforts are projected
to increase crop yield by almost a quarter
over the next few decades. If combined with methods
to combat deforestation in the region, they could move the country toward a resilient, climate-focused
agricultural sector. And in India, where up to 40 percent
of post-harvest food is lost or wasted due to poor infrastructure, farmers have already started to implement
solar-powered cold storage capsules that help thousands of rural farmers
preserve their produce and become a viable part
of the supply chain. It will take all of these methods, from the most high-tech
to the lowest-cost, to revolutionize farming. High-tech interventions stand to amplify climate- and conservation-oriented
approaches to farming, and large producers will need to invest
in implementing these technologies. Meanwhile, we'll have to expand access
to the lower-cost methods for smaller-scale farmers. This vision of future farming
will also require a global shift toward more plant-based diets and huge reductions
in food loss and waste, both of which will reduce
pressure on the land and allow farmers to do more
with what they have available. If we optimize food production,
both on land and sea, we can feed humanity within the environmental
limits of the earth, but there's a very small margin of error, and it will take unprecedented
global cooperation and coordination of the agricultural
lands we have today.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What are some characteristics of future farms?
Options: A. Low-cost agricultural practices, B. Use of high-tech interventions such as drones and sensors, C. Intertwined farmland and natural habitats, D. All of the above
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the primary outcome of the first agricultural revolution? Options: A. The expansion of farmland led to an increase in greenhouse gas emissions., B. The development of new farming techniques led to a significant decrease in crop yields., C. The first agricultural revolution enabled the existence of civilization by providing a stable food source., D. The first agricultural revolution led to a significant decrease in forest cover. Correct Option: C
Question 2: What is the main goal of the next agricultural revolution? Options: A. To increase the output of existing farmland while protecting biodiversity and reducing pollution., B. To expand farmland at the expense of forests and wildlife and water., C. To develop new farming techniques that reduce crop yields., D. To decrease greenhouse gas emissions by reducing food production. Correct Option: A
Question 3: How can farmers in the future use drones to monitor crops? Options: A. By planting multiple crops in the same field., B. By using targeted doses of fertilizer and monitoring soil nutrients and water levels., C. By clearing large swathes of land and planting a single crop., D. By using high-tech interventions to amplify climate- and conservation-oriented approaches to farming. Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is the significance of the increase in forest cover in Costa Rica? Options: A. It has led to a significant decrease in greenhouse gas emissions., B. It has provided food and habitat for wildlife as well as natural pollination and pest control., C. It has led to a significant increase in crop yields., D. It has led to a significant decrease in forest biodiversity. Correct Option: B
Question 5: What is the main advantage of using solar-powered cold storage capsules in India? Options: A. It has led to a significant increase in crop yields., B. It has helped thousands of rural farmers preserve their produce and become a viable part of the supply chain., C. It has led to a significant decrease in greenhouse gas emissions., D. It has led to a significant decrease in food loss and waste. Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is the projected impact of locally specific methods to improve crop production in Zambia? Options: A. It will lead to a significant decrease in crop yields., B. It will increase crop yield by almost a quarter over the next few decades., C. It will lead to a significant increase in greenhouse gas emissions., D. It will lead to a significant decrease in forest cover. Correct Option: B
Question 7: What is the main challenge of feeding humanity within the environmental limits of the earth? Options: A. It will require a significant decrease in food production., B. It will require a global shift toward more plant-based diets and huge reductions in food loss and waste., C. It will require a significant increase in greenhouse gas emissions., D. It will require a significant decrease in forest cover. Correct Option: B
Question 8: What is the significance of the development of new strains of rice in Bangladesh, Cambodia, and Nepal? Options: A. It has led to a significant increase in greenhouse gas emissions., B. It has increased incomes and crop yields while cutting down on greenhouse gas emissions., C. It has led to a significant decrease in forest cover., D. It has led to a significant decrease in crop yields. Correct Option: B
Question 9: What is the main advantage of using locally specific methods to improve crop production in Zambia? Options: A. It will lead to a significant increase in greenhouse gas emissions., B. It will increase crop yield by almost a quarter over the next few decades., C. It will lead to a significant decrease in food loss and waste., D. It will lead to a significant decrease in forest cover. Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is the main goal of the vision of future farming? Options: A. To expand farmland at the expense of forests, wildlife, and water., B. To increase the output of existing farmland while protecting biodiversity and reducing pollution., C. To develop new farming techniques that reduce crop yields., D. To decrease greenhouse gas emissions by reducing food production. Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

A more suitable match can be found by combining the options from multiple generated MCQs. However, if I had to choose one generated MCQ that closest matches the intent and content of the ground truth MCQ, I would choose:

 Question 10: What is the main goal of the vision of future farming? Options: A. To expand farmland at the expense of forests, wildlife, and water., B. To increase the output of existing farmland while protecting biodiversity and reducing pollution., C. To develop new farming techniques that reduce crop yields., D. To decrease greenhouse gas emissions by reducing food production.

However, please note that this is not an exact match, as the ground truth MCQ asks about the characteristics of future farms, while Question 10 asks about the main goal of the vision of future farming.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 9, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Transcriber: TED Translators Admin
Reviewer: Mirjana Čutura About 10,000 years ago,
humans began to farm. This agricultural revolution
was a turning point in our history that enabled people to settle,
build and create. In short, agriculture
enabled the existence of civilization. Today, approximately 40 percent
of our planet is farmland. Spread all over the world, these agricultural lands
are the pieces to a global puzzle we are all facing: in the future, how can we feed
every member of a growing population a healthy diet? Meeting this goal will require nothing short of a second
agricultural revolution. The first agricultural revolution was characterized
by expansion and exploitation, feeding people at the expense
of forests, wildlife and water and destabilizing the climate
in the process. That's not an option the next time around. Agriculture depends on a stable climate with predictable seasons
and weather patterns. This means we can't keep
expanding our agricultural lands, because doing so will undermine
the environmental conditions that make agriculture possible
in the first place. Instead, the next agricultural revolution will have to increase the output
of our existing farmland for the long term while protecting biodiversity,
conserving water and reducing pollution
and greenhouse gas emissions. So what will the future farms look like? This drone is part of a fleet
that monitors the crops below. The farm may look haphazard but is a delicately engineered
use of the land that intertwines crops and livestock
with wild habitats. Conventional farming methods
cleared large swathes of land and planted them with a single crop, eradicating wildlife and emitting huge amounts
of greenhouse gases in the process. This approach aims to correct that damage. Meanwhile, moving among the crops, teams of field robots
apply fertilizer in targeted doses. Inside the soil, hundreds of sensors gather data
on nutrients and water levels. This information reduces
unnecessary water use and tells farmers where they should apply
more and less fertilizer instead of causing pollution
by showering it across the whole farm. But the farms of the future
won't be all sensors and robots. These technologies are designed
to help us produce food in a way that works with the environment rather than against it, taking into account
the nuances of local ecosystems. Lower-cost agricultural practices
can also serve those same goals and are much more accessible
to many farmers. In fact, many such practices
are already in use today and stand to have
an increasingly large impact as more farmers adopt them. In Costa Rica, farmers have intertwined farmland
with tropical habitat so successfully that they have significantly contributed
to doubling the country's forest cover. This provides food
and habitat for wildlife as well as natural pollination
and pest control from the birds and insects
these farms attract, producing food while restoring the planet. In the United States, ranchers are raising cattle
on grasslands composed of native species, generating a valuable protein source using production methods that store carbon
and protect biodiversity. In Bangladesh, Cambodia and Nepal, new approaches to rice production may dramatically decrease
greenhouse gas emissions in the future. Rice is a staple food
for three billion people and the main source of livelihood
for millions of households. More than 90 percent of rice
is grown in flooded paddies, which use a lot of water and release 11 percent
of annual methane emissions, which accounts for one to two percent of total annual greenhouse gas
emissions globally. By experimenting with new strains of rice, irrigating less and adopting less labor-intensive
ways of planting seeds, farmers in these countries have already increased
their incomes and crop yields while cutting down
on greenhouse gas emissions. In Zambia, numerous organizations
are investing in locally specific methods to improve crop production,
reduce forest loss and improve livelihoods for local farmers. These efforts are projected
to increase crop yield by almost a quarter
over the next few decades. If combined with methods
to combat deforestation in the region, they could move the country toward a resilient, climate-focused
agricultural sector. And in India, where up to 40 percent
of post-harvest food is lost or wasted due to poor infrastructure, farmers have already started to implement
solar-powered cold storage capsules that help thousands of rural farmers
preserve their produce and become a viable part
of the supply chain. It will take all of these methods, from the most high-tech
to the lowest-cost, to revolutionize farming. High-tech interventions stand to amplify climate- and conservation-oriented
approaches to farming, and large producers will need to invest
in implementing these technologies. Meanwhile, we'll have to expand access
to the lower-cost methods for smaller-scale farmers. This vision of future farming
will also require a global shift toward more plant-based diets and huge reductions
in food loss and waste, both of which will reduce
pressure on the land and allow farmers to do more
with what they have available. If we optimize food production,
both on land and sea, we can feed humanity within the environmental
limits of the earth, but there's a very small margin of error, and it will take unprecedented
global cooperation and coordination of the agricultural
lands we have today.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Revolutionizing farming will require
Options: A. Decreasing low-cost farming practices, B. A global shift toward plant-based diets, C. Optimizing food production and reducing food loss, D. Both B and C are correct
Correct Option: D
